editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: The Knave in Graine, New Vampt. A witty Comedy, Acted at the Fortune many dayes together with great Applauſe. Written by J. D. Gent.
LONDON: Printed by J. O. and are to be ſold by John Nicholſon at his Shop under St. Martins Church neare Ludgate. 1640.

div.head: To the Generous Reader.
div.p: COurteous Reader, the ancient Latin Adage is, Sultorum, but I ſay Nebulonum plena ſunt omnia, Knaves be about all perſons, and in all places. There are twelve Coat-Cards in the bunch, of which foure are Knaves, Heart, Diamond, Spade, Club, ſuiting with the foure C C C C: Court, City, Country, Campe: My purpoſe is not to touch any in particular; onely thus much of them in generall: ſome are notable, ſome notorious, ſome pimping, ſome panderly Knaves; ſome prating, ſome peſtilent; ſome couſening, ſome cunny-catching Knaves. There are alſo lazy and lying, baſe, and deboiſt, fantaſticall, fooliſh, and falſe Knaves. To theſe we may adde Hereticall and Hypocriticall, ſchiſmaticall, and ſepariſticall Knaves: not forgetting perjur'd, and ſhameleſſe; impudent, and informing; arrogant, and arrant Knaves, Cum multis alijs. And beſides theſe, I have heard of a Knave Tapſter, a Knave Oſtler, a Knave Serjeant, and a Knave Broker: but with theſe we have nothing to doe at this time; onely with a Knave in graine, or a Knave new vampt, in decyphering of whom, I give all the reſt this Caveat, Have amongſt you my Maſters: And now if any of the reſt ſhall finde himſelfe touch't, hee hath his mends in his owne hands, for he cannot ſay but I gave him faire warning. And ſo much of the Argument, the Act followes.

list.item: A rabble of Boyes and others.

div.head: Actus primus. Scena prima.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: WHy how now Puſs, what ayles my Monkie to chatter out of tune thus?

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: A whoreſon ſenceleſſe Coxcombe— but I am glad th'art come, I long for a pottle of wine and a Capon.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Good proviſion for the preſent Monkie, but viderit futuritas, in the meane time, who layes up for futurity? Come you raiſe foure hundred per annum, out of pottles of Wine and Capons?

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: Yes my Granado, in this qualitie: they that come ſhort of my breeding have don't. The firſt credit I wonne was in a Garriſon.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: In Holland.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: No; and yet in the low Countries: I never ſate foot in a leaguer yet.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: The reaſon of that?

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: My hard fate nothing elſe, having as much impudence, and as many wayes to manage it, receiving weekly Corantoes from Paris, Roterdam, and Fluſhing, and having trade too in Middleborough, I have beene houſe Lecturer three yeares together, and read Aretine, both in print and picture, and that is much for one of my yeares.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: 'T may be thou wantſt acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: No ſuch matter, the old Exchange, the new Burſe, and new Town, afford plenty; not a Prentice that can cry Bawd, nor a Butchers Dog that can ſay bow wow, but is of my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Yet it may be they are preciſe, and will not be ſeen in't.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: That I know not, but moſt ſure, I have feaſted the Liberty twice at mine owne charge, and helpt their wives and daughters to the earning of many a fair pound: they will be ſeen in that.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Well, I am ſure I have furniſh'd thy Library with all books of behaviour, and tables of entertainment.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p:
And I have cull'd out all my phraſes as curiouſly & ſtuck my language with ſuch inticing conveniences: and for intellicence, all the lawn women, lace women, box women, and to come nearer to the buſineſſe, very haire women, perriwig women, and candied Elicumpany lick halbars, come in twice a week like decoy Ducks, with whole ſholes at the
• aile of them.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Why, then there's a fault in your company.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: I, I, that villanous company undoes all, Ther's Lodowick Tomaſo Vallentine, high talkers, and deepe drinkers, but they have wit in their wine, and too much honeſty in their actions at all time, there's only on Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Stultiſſimo of a plain cut and ſquare ſize, he runs juſt as you throw him; rub him a little againſt the grain now, and he will come off a great deal the ſmoother. You would not thinke, what charitable benefactours three or foure ſuch pluſh Colonels would be to the founding of a new honour.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: But haſt thou ſuch a purpoſe, indeed?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Why ſhould not I have purpoſe and effect as much as any: A leager, yes, ſo it lay in the Ile of plentie; Ide dig through the Alpes with Haniball, and fetch Theſeus from Hell, with Hercules purpoſe and practice, my precious Monkie, tis done.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: And ſhall I come to the honour to write Miſtris of the Leaguer.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Shall not bate an accent of that title my Catamptiall Monky, but you muſt look out for Spiders Monky, and the Sprall of all foure Puzz: I have laid the foundation in gold already.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: Haſt had a good return of thy Rings chuck?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Rings hangum, they are as ſtale as Scotch Lanſon, Or as your Decoy,
No, I have ſent um out in a deſperat venture to Cape.
No Monkie, my old friend Franciſcus hath repaired my Jacket already, & has promiſed to new thatch my outſide too.
One of theſe boxes has 100 pieces of new gold,
With chains and keyes correſpondent.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.p: For what uſe Chick?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: For a dead lift Monkie: a Leaguer cannot be planted, mann'd, victuall'd and munition'd with a ſmall Magazine: to work Monkie, a mouzing Puſs, make choice of your company, admit no parley with the popular, be high and proud of thy ſelfe, and let thoſe that will needs buy thee, pay ſoundly for thee with a pox to um, Puſs a wink to the wiſe, you know my minde, let's have no more midnight catterwowlings under Sale-mens ſhop windows, Vintners dark cellers, no Juſtices long Entries, but beare up your ſelfe ſo civill and ſo meager▪
You may be ſtilde a ſiſter of the Leaguer.

div.stage: Enter Dulciflora a Whore, and Miſtris Durable a Bawd, old Signior Stultiſſimo a fooliſh Gentleman, and Fub.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Away you Rogue.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: As I am a Gentleman body and ſoule Ile break your windowes.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Maſter, as you are a man ſtand and tickle her.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Will you, you Raſcall.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Ah, ſweet heart, prethee good woman.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Nay, let her come Ile give her hert belly full.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Let her alone Fub: let her alone, by this hand, Ile make the boyes maule her Ruffs.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Fie how I am tyred a whorſon ſtinking ſhamleg'd, Fie, fie, fie, uſe a Gentlewoman thus in her own lodging.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: How does your back, O the Fucas, out alas, here's half a Crown in Complexion utterly caſt away.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: If I be not even with the Rutter—

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: If hee come where you have to doe, let him pay ſoundly.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: A plague upon his Aſſes eares, by my Virginity, Ile ſend his beard into New-found-land for this.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: And ſo I would, to make lines to catch Cods: out, out, out, a Gentleman, and uſe a woman no otherwiſe; yfaith, yfath, it ſtands not with his reputation.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: A whorſon ſmelt: Miſtris Durable, I would I had ſome of your aqua vitae, I'me ſick after the conflict.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: And ſhall good woman, come, come, pray keep your ſelf warme.

div.stage: Enter Franciſcus, and Julio, Julio very poore.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Forſake me honour, when I doe forget the bond of friendſhip, let not poverty, no, nor your fathers haviour Julio: though our Venetian law proved him a Traitor: come
plucke away your intereſt from my breaſt: when we were pupills in the Academy, I was Franciſcus and your fellow then; I am Franciſcus and your fellow ſtill, nor can be altered: I have now a heart as free from pride, as when I clipt thee thus, before thou knew'ſt the taſte of poverty, or I proſperity. Thinke not ancient friend I can forget thee, though thy need were ſuch as beggery deſpis'd.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: The liberall hand of heaven reward your love, or lend my wiſhes that ability to thank you in requitall.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Amen to that and more.

I tell thee Iulio, I am not happier in my vertuous wife: and yet that's greater than yielding thee reliefe tis all that good men wiſh: Why have we wealth beſtow'd on us, but to returne the ſame, where ſtern neceſſity pinches the ribs of him or her that wants? it has no other worth, no more eſteeme of me. Heap it together while the, maſſie weight e'ne crack, what bears it leſſe than duſt? on duſt deſerves no more regard. I have a Wife, Nurſe, and mother, all ſhe is in one; yet one deſerves more Titles, beſides her feature, which may make compare with thoſe that boaſt of parts: ſhe is ſo kinde, that many millions may be ſtampt againe, ere one ſo perfect currant. She is worth more than the earth is: but ſhe is my wife, and I will ceaſe her praiſe: you know her father when you have his name: hee is called Chriſippus, many ſtile him good, and wiſh all Venice ſuch.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Ere I was baniſh'd for my fathers fact, my knowledge coated, and all Italy, ſpoke of a Damoſell called Cornelia, this good Chriſippus daughter.

div.stage: Enter Chriſippus, Cornelia, Anthonio, Tomaſo, Phemono, Stultiſſimo, and Fub.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: She is that jewell, that unmatched, thing I made my boaſt of: That Cornelia is none but mine, I dare boldly ſay, and eke affirme it: See my Julio, ſhe meets us unexpected, and comes to hinder what I would ſpeake more, in cauſe of her demerit, modeſty, and ſweetneſſe.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Franciſcus: ſonne!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My Love and duty make me ever ſuch.
To all this company a happy houre.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: You have bin miſt Franciſcus.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You have beene miſt Cornelia.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Where ere I have bin, this is my friend, tender him your welcome with as good reſpects as I my ſelfe where he.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Sir, bid your own welcome, and command as much as all we have, were yours.

sp.speaker: Iulio
sp.p: Your courteſies to one ſo throng'd in miſery As my ſelfe, dulls my behaviour, that I know not how Enough to laud or thanke you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You ſhall exchange your habit:
Phemone, ſiſter, Anthonio—

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: We miſt you yeſter night.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I durſt not come believe it:
Vallentius for ſayes rowſes are too great,
They make me quake to ſee 'em.
How fares my couſen Lodwick?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: He ſpoyld our ſport: he was not well he ſaid:
I would you had beene there: Tomaſo pledg'd you twice.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I thank his love.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: It is not worth it Sir.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Yfaith Nephew I was extream drunke, aske my man Fub elſe, he'le tell you what a coyle he had with me: the rareſt leſt yfaith: prethee tell 'em how thou foundſt me underneath the ſtaires.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: By no meanes, 'twill make 'em drunk to heare it.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Signior Arbaces you are the man I wiſht for.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Well met Gentlemen: are you here Antonio?

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Cornelia.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: No, tis no matter. Tomaſo you ſhall do't,
Goe ſee nothing want; you are all my gueſts, you dine with
Me that's certaine: Nay, I will not be deny'd:
Moſt welcome Sir to you: will you walke?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ever, ever welcome.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Will you walk ſir? will you munch?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Sirrah Fub, thou wouldſt not think how ſore my head is, ever ſince I had the knock with the Ladle?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: I believe you: will you feed ſir?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: No more i'th' Ladle. Me thinkes I am pocky melancholy here of late.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: So I gheſt, ever ſince you knew the Gentlewoman that beate you.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Thou ſayeſt true, ever ſince yfaith.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Why ſhe is able to make any body pocky melancholy. But would you would ſnap a bit ſir.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: I love her I cannot tell how: yfaith and I were well ſearch'd, I think I am little kin to a Spannell, the more I am beaten, the better I affect.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Would I were ſure of that.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Well, ſhe ſhall heare from me in ſome Sonnet or Ditty; ſome rare thing of mine owne invention, and that ſpeedily: Let me ſee to what tune ſhall I have it?

sp.speaker: Fub.
Stultiſ.
sp.p: By this hand gramercy; they doe indeed, thou canſt ſing if need be.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: I can make a ſcurvy ſhift: But to ſay truth I am no good Queriſter.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: But canſt thou doe well and ſcurvily?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: After my manner.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Would I might be hang'd preſently, but methinkes I am a piece of a Poet already, there's ſuch a whiſtling in my pate.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: That's nothing but your conceit ſir.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Conceit merrily: O that my love were any thing but woman.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: O that your love were any thing but Common: then might ſhe be.—

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.p: What might ſhe be.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Nay what you wil yfaith.

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.p: Ile to't while tis hot, I know I'me in an excellent vein.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Pricke it quickly then:
But Harke you Signior, ſhall you not need my helpe?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: I defie't, It ſhall be all mine own, I cannot abide, tis the ſcurvieſt thing to rob others of their wit, good or bad, it ſhall flow from mine own ſweet brain.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: I believe youle finde the tyde turn'd, tis ebbing water there, would I might be begg'd, as hee had like to have been, if his foolery do not vex my diſcretion, but hee gives me means, and I could do little if I could not ſmile.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Well Vallentius, and you be caught ith' purlues: and you be not ſtung for't Ile forſweare privacie, and all that belongs too •• , I have a Girle, the very ſpirit of what ſhe was made for, and ſhe were honeſt, ſhe might crave ſupremacie of Hellen, and make her ride behinde.

sp.speaker: Vallen.
sp.p: And I love one were ſhe not honeſt, that's her only fault, ſhee were a Paragon unparalleld, mingle all beautie that our Venice yields, and ſet her ſelf aſide, ſhe would ſtand peerleſſe, over-ſhine them all, and dimme the Artiſts cunning.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Is ſhe a woman?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Yes, but ſuch a one no voluntary habit, nor ſlie drift with all accommodations that beſeemes, unblemiſht truth it ſelfe can bring to ſpeech or give my thoughts acceſſe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What is ſhe for a Saint, that ſtands in the how faire and beautifull: may one of my birth intreat her name and knowledge?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: Vow your aſſiſtance to my purpoſes, and I a Traitour to my ſelfe reveale the treaſon of my minde.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Give me your hand, I am yours for better or worſe, in all cauſes, all adventures, my ſword and ſelfe vow fealty: Is ſhe a wife?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: I, would ſhe were not.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Know you Vanderman our great Phyſician.

sp.speaker: Vall.
Vall.
sp.p: You know hee's married.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes, and what of this (oh would you be miniſtring therein.) I have you my deare Flora, well take my word ſhee's thine.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: I would that I were hers.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why it lyes in thine own choice.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: But ſetting all this pleaſantneſſe aſide, in earneſt Lodowick I affect her ſo, no motive mean nor yet dire accident can change my ſtedfaſt will, I muſt enjoy her, or I muſt not live.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt enjoy her, or I will not live.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: You ſpeak like a friend.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I ſpeak like what I am, a Chriſtian, and by that Epethite, I meant as much as I ſpeake, nor could I thinke, Vallentius, you of all the men alive, would have miſtaken mee.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: In any kinde but this I never had: pardon me Lodowick this doting loves beares ſuch a jealous ſway, the leaſt ſuſpition puts us on the wracke, and breaks all chaines of duty: You may perſwade me to believe, but yet he that never ſaw a Veſſell under ſayle, cannot imagine what the Seaman brooks, the Merchant ſleeping on his downey Cowch, nere dreams what danger the bold Souldie • r dures, and he that never felt the pangs of Hell, cannot report the torments: aſſure thee Lodowick ſo be ſatisfied, ſince I knew her, I have not known my ſelfe, ſo mighty is loves extreams.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Tis ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: She troth plight was to me, and had been mine, had not deſire of pelfe alter'd her friends, and I dare well vow ſhe loved me once, what ere her minde be now.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Come be rul'd by mee, thou ſhalt ſet thy toe in the Doctors ſtirrop, ride and go a foot at thy pleaſure: did ſhee love thee once?

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: I had her oath.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Go to, renew thy ſuite, the fire is not all out, ſtir up
the aſhes, and thou doſt not finde ſome embers, that will both glow and warme, pawn me for butter'd Sack, and let me never be worthy redemption.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I want the means.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Think not of that, tis here my Flora, what man? he's not the firſt Doctor has worn a corner Cap: come, will you be merry Vallentius, and youle forſake not this mood, I renounce ſociety.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am yours, obedient as your hand.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Follow me then, and I drive not this melancholly fit out of thee, Ile never truſt my conceit: what, ho Damazella? Knocks, and Clariſlona looks out at the window.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Whoſe there?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: He's here that ſhould be here, come down?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Lodowick.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What's ſhe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: The commodity I told you of, there's a Gentleman a friend of yours in love with her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No faith, though you ſhall heare her ſweare as much, tis our rich heire Signior Stultiſſimo.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: What, the Foole?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: That mor ſell of mans fleſh, ſhee cannot beat him away, he haunts the Eves like a Sparrow in March, you may hunt flies from honey ſooner then him out of her company: now Miſtris how ſtands things with you, when did you play with your fools bable?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Youle never leave this.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Bid my friend welcome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I thank you Lady.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Come kiſſe me?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Will you ſtay all night?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes, when I am weary of ſtrength, and foes with my back.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Yfaith Lodowick, you muſt leave this?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: So I will▪

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: When thou leav'ſt thy trade?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Will you ſup here?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes drink, nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Lord, how wiſe your grown?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: So I were, if I could keep out of your company.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Fie, your'e to uncourteous Lodwick: nay, he's ever thus, but tis my fault.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Marry mend it then for ſhame.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Where's my Bracelet, which of your Truls has that?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Shall I be true to thee?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Your'e nere true to me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I mean honeſt.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: I care not for your honeſty.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I believe that too, but in plain verity. Your bracelet embraces my horſes main.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Come, you jeſt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No good troth.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Sweare you, I hope you make a difference between your horſe and me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Faith but little: and yet your'e both good bearers.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: By the bright Sun you wrong her: weepe not faire one.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What, ſhall we have tricks?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are too blame beſhrow me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Now, when, what needs all this, nay, and you powt farewell.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: As I am a Gentleman you part not ſo.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Sweet, Lodwick.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hum, why was not this before, I have ſeene the Beares.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Do not I know your woman?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Hiſt, hiſt, Are you the man of War?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay, you muſt draw neerer, if youle have your Embaſſie anſwered: how iſt Miſtris Durable?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: How do you Maſter Lodowick?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: The worſe for you, and your creatures.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: It's a good hearing.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Shall I have three or foure words in private?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Not with her unleſſe I participate.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Yonder's Fub, the parties man you wot on has ſomthing under hand and ſeale.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: For me.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: So he gives out.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: You may admit him.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Reſt you merry Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Whoſe this ſecret party, this conceal'd Champion▪ What have ye here, Signior Stuliiſſimoes man?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: All haile.

sp.speaker: Vall.
sp.p: This fellow would keep a vilde coyle if hee were a top ath' tiles.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Gentiles, good ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What, the Plough?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: No, you, and you pleaſe, Marona to your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: This fellows diſcreet.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: To me.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: So ſayes his backſide.

sp.speaker: Iulio
sp.p: You the man of War, or more properly Pirat, that gave ſummons to the leaguer.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Leager, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Leager, Sir, the report of your Pot-guns cannot make us hang up a white flag.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: The skirt of a clean ſmock's more proper ath' two.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Wee come not to learne whats proper of you, Monkie, and catch flies.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Play at his foolery, come hither Punck.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Sir, y'are uncivill, ſhe's none; nor this a Bawdy houſe; but a Leaguer of gentle entertainment.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: The fellow dreames: Come wake and be thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: My ſelfe? Would you were as ſure your ſelves as I am.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: A what?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I'de faine know that of you:
But I adviſe you to take councell of your beſt judgment firſt,
Your words will be queſtioned.

sp.speaker: Lodw.
sp.p: Queſtion that dares, th'art an arrant Cheater.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Tis not your pare royall of pluſh Coxecombes can ſecure you in't.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.p: Valiant a the ſuddaine too.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Not ſuddainly neither:
The growth has both time and ſufficient temper.
Why I a Cheater? let any impartiall—
Ride Circuit, and ſit in judgement of us all,
And ſhew any reaſon either in Art or Nature,
Why I a Cheater more than any of you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Thou haſt nothing but a little wit to live upon.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: That's endowment enough for a Gentleman:
I ever ſhall count him the nobler gentleman
That makes himſelfe a fortune in the world, than he
That brings it into the world with him.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Suppoſe this granted: yet why this a Leaguer?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: I want words for you: onely for concluſion, one out of a ſtrange affected carriage has gathered an admirable method of drilling, and training men from the flying of Cranes: Another rare order and government of Common-wealths, from the poore labour of the Bee: And I out of this Leaguer—

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.p: Will extract certaine wayes and carriages for Cheaters and Libertines.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
Twere not from my purpoſe if I granted that to. Lycurgus was the firſt Law-maker; and the beſt Law that ever he made, was a proviſion or maintenance for Cheats, as you call em, and Fellons (viz.) That he (without exception of
age, quality, or condition) which could doe the moſt high dainty, and dangerous peece of Felony, and come cleare off, ſhould be preferred to the moſt eminent place of office in the State; but if he failed, he was then to receive Martiall Law.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.p: Strange courſe, pick Officers out of Fellons.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: 'Tis a kind of Meſlin or mingled graine ſtill. How much of the poores money was found in one of the Churchwardens purchaſe laſt day?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: None I thinke.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: How many theeves horſes have bin watered at the High Conſtable of the hundreds watring trough within this tenne yeares?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I think not any.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: It may be ſo: But I am ſure, I have heard, or read▪ or ſomething, that a new Chiefe Juſtice of ſome place, or a better man wo'd not ha made very nice to bid a fat purſe to breakfaſt with him if he light upon it ſoundly: ſo that it is not ſo much the Art to know, as the government to diſpoſe: that quallifies the man.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.p: He ſayes true: all times ha' bin guilty of good fellowſhip, why not this? I like the Leaguer now ſo well, I care not if I buy a place of command in it my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Why now you come to me,
That's the Pearle I ha • div'd for all this while:
I have a catalogue of names, places, and prizes.
A cup of entertainment for my friend.
Welcome to the new Leaguer.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.l: We'le pledge, we'le pledge:
Victual'd and Win'd already?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
Lod.
sp.p: How now Iulio, gold?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: By this light, and the moſt curious.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
A poore Grannams gift gentlemen: 300 peeces, or ſuch a taſte, par • ly induction to a buſineſſe, or ſo. There's a
Burdeaux Merchant in Towne now, would lay me between wind and water this twelve month, but the ſpite is, I am tyed not to part with this gold for ever: if I knew where to borrow but halfe the worth on't—

sp.speaker: Lodw.
sp.l: Halfe the worth?
Ile vow to lend the full worth,
If that will pleaſure thee.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: You ſhall keepe the gold under locke and key for your pawne.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt not want for ſuch a courteſie to doe thee good: Ime glad th'art ſo thriving.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Lock up the boxe, and keep the key; there's the full ſumme.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: To a Piece I aſſure you: you ſhall ſee elſe agen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No more, no more trouble:
Let me ſee for how long?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Three Moneths, not a day longer:
Nay ſooner if mony chance to come in afore:
I have offices in my Leaguer ſtand upon Fortunes hill.
'Vds me Signior Stultiſſimo promi • ed
Me a courteſie laſt night:

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: Aſſure thee ſweet chuck he'le not faile thee.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: I believe thee without an oath:
Make my friend welcome to the Leaguer Monkey:
As ſoone as I have diſpatch'd my voyage
To the Canaries, I am for you agen Lads.

sp.speaker: Whor.
sp.p: Gentlemen, who can read?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Who cannot?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: I can reſolve you:
She cannot.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What's here?
Opprobrious Saint, and moſt Angellicke fiend,
Ere I begin, thus doe I make an end.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I ſhould have beene ſorry elſe:
Nay ſilence, or the Proclamation's loſt.
And if thy heart be not patcht up in Marble,
Harke how my pen does in thy prayſes warble.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O deare Apollo, how art thou abus'd, Is there more?

lg.l: Sweet ſtinging Waſpe, and well conceited Dove▪
For beauty nice, intituled Queen of love
Of me; Sir reverence; that doe's thee adore;
Which art eſteem'd a good one and no more:
Let reaſon rule thy Amazonian ſiſt▪
Let ladle rude be thrown at hady wiſt,
So ſhall I love thee, take it for no fable
Better then well, and more then I am able.

closer.signed: Yours deſpite your guts. S. S.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Aſſe, Aſſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The Authours name.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Cannot you get her Signior Stultiſſimo?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O, lamentable complaint!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: As ever poore man heard.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Will he take no warning.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Is this a Challenge?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Fie no, they are too violent to come in rime.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Lodowick, is not this your practice?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why, doſt thou think me ſo ſimple, ſo ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: No, Ile aſſure you, It's a token of good will of my Maſters, there's no brain guilty ont but his own: if you like it you may, and you will not, the laws in your own hands, you may chooſe.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Good Gentlemen return the Carrier.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What? a cuffe or a knock.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Hee has penn'd a Song too, which I ſhould have tickled, if I had not been hoarſe with drinking Flap-Dragons laſt night.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Whats thy name?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Fub.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Prethee honeſt Fub, tickle thy ſelfe out of our companies, weele be Fubb'd no longer.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Will not you be Fubb'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Thou knoweſt my reſolution.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Nay, but will ye not indeed?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No faith▪

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: I am glad I know't,—be with you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Have you any wine ith' houſe?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Yes deareſt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Come, a pox a theſe devices, hang off: will you drink Vallentius?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Will I live?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Where's the Matron?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: The Matron, Lord, you're the ſtrangeſt man.—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Your Matron Grandum, what will you have it, your Bawd?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: I muſt be quiet.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Nay, enter, enter.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: The eaſie time, and ſuch as thrive in it, favour my wiſhes, the ignorant whoſe ſole dependance is on veritie, and carry conſcience in their timorous breſts, are not aſſociates meet for Iulio. Thoſe that neere knew the ſtraine of Policie, nor ayme at more, then what may well content, draw not my length, the way to proſper, the directeſt courſe ſuch are my ſore neceſſities, is to get liking of this lovely Maid Franciſcus ſiſter, bright Phemone, the Virgin's modeſt, chaſt, and debonaire, beſides her brother's rich, there hang my hopes, but ſhee affects not mee, all her deſires are on young Anthonios, rich Arbaces ſonne, my friend (ſuppos'd) at leaſt, but that is breath; by what man has, or can have, he's my foe that hinders my deſigne, where hee my next of bloud, that ſhall he finde: the meane to purchaſe what I reach at now, there is but only one, one only meane that can ſupplant him, here it lies ſhall doo't, were hee as deare in eſtimation as Niſus to Eurialus.
sp.l: I love my ſelfe, I count him ſtill moſt wiſe,
That cares not who's thrown down ſo he ariſe.

div.head: Actus ſecundus. Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter Franciſcus and Julio. ſound Muſick.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: THou haſt to ſay ſomthing, yet nothing I hope triviall, by our known affection I beſeech thee, ſpeak what thou canſt.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: I would I had embraced my povertie, while the pale Moone has reſidence in heaven, would I had beene deafe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Whereto tends this ſpeech if I thought my fault, or any ones pertain'd to mee, through wilfull negligence, or otherwiſe, to breed the occaſion of this paſſionate mood, I ſhould condemne the cauſe of the offence, and deeme my ſelf unhappy.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Can heaven ſuffer it?

sp.speaker: Fran,
sp.p: What, what does heaven ſuffer, ſpeak my Iulio?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Too much of ill.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Let me know that ill, and I reſt ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Pray no more, the malady is mortall, unſanctified, monſtrous. Anthonio is there ſuch a man?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Many that weare that name in Italy: but one amongſt that many known to me.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Hate all the name.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pardon Iulio, Ile hate my ſelfe firſt.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Anthonio is a Villain.

sp.speaker: Fran,
sp.p:
Blot not the reputation of his youth with ſuch
calumnie, he is no way ſuch, but as unblemiſht, as the ſnow before it touch the Mountains.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: He's a Villain.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Villain never had ſo faire an out-ſide, nor yet heart ſo juſt as that he carries.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: He's a Villain.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I have ſome buſineſſe at the Port, youle ſup with me to night.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Doe you love your ſelfe, do you love honour, do you love your wife?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Then hate that Anthonio.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Give me to underſtand, ſince you will force me to endure your report, wherein hee's culpable, or does deſerve theſe ignominious titles.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: He loves not you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Tis not my fault.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: He wrongs your ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Therein, he's too blame.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: He loves your wife.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That amends, quits all his former wrongs.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Can you beare it thus, wink Vulcan then,
And let the god of Warre, throw up her skirts agen.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: You will not underſtand; Ile ſpeak no further.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Come, come, my wife is honeſt.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: If ſhe be, tis nothing you have ſaid, Ile heare no more; begon.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Will you liſt a word, Anthonio wongs you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Wrong me, and if he would he cannot.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: He playes the Paraſite, the officious Aſſe to vaile his ſinne.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Would I might underſtand you?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: The Serpent tempts your wife, theſe eares and eyes can teſtifie; for your ſiſter, ſhe's ſtale: his excuſe, whereby hee cloakes his vice.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I wiſh you Iulio, to know what you ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: I am not mad, I love you, tis my love, you are my father.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I pray be adviſed, conſider what you do? ſpeak not this no report, be certain; do not abuſe my patience. Tempt my wife, rent earth, and ſwallow falſhood.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Will you be moved Pernaſſus, the two topt, forked Mount?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My bloud is not mine own, I want command of all that now obeyed me, how different are my fits? I am now a congealed, kneaded cake of ice, bound from all motion, now again (mee thinks) a flaming Iland, a Veſunius Hill, meerly combuſtion.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Forget not, ſir, your patience.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Tell me of patience when I am my ſelfe: how did he tempt her, how did ſhe accord on thy reputation?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: I would I had been dumbe?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hang not ith' winde, (delay does torture) anſwer me as how?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Kinde, ſir, recall your wonted manhood?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Anſwer me how.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: I pray pardon me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What? ſtrike and cry mercie, I muſt be reſolved, thou haſt flung me ith' fire, even in the Oven, the mouth of Aetna, nothing thou coulſt have ſaid, nothing have done, could have aſſured like torture.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Would, when I ſaw him kiſſe her, cruſh her hand, wink and laugh out, uſe his undecent language: Fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Cornelia falſe, the floud may come agen, nothing impoſſible, kiſſe, and cruſh hands, wink, wink heaven and all above.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Kind, ſir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Beare witneſſe, all that good are, how deare, how deare, I held that moſt falſe man: ſet him here, here, even on the ſpire and pinacle of my heart; my life was his, and all that I call mine, but her he has abuſed?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p:
Deare friend, do not forget your name, theſe are but likelihoods, farre from the thing it ſelfe, and ſay he be a Villaine,
as no doubt he's little better in his rude expoſures: ſhe may be honeſt.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No Julio, no, had ſhe meant well,
She would have warnd me of his foule attempts,
Said ſuch, and ſo's his haviour.
When ſhe was loyall, as ſure one ſhee was,
(If ever any was) no accident how vaine
So e're it ſeemed, but ſhe a woman, would unfold
Her ſexe, and ſay 'twas thus, and thus.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: I have ſtroke him through.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Treble abuſe:
Deflowred my wife, abuſed me,
Diſgraced my ſiſter; throwne infamy
On all our heads at once: What beaſt uncivill bred,
Amongſt careleſſe Monſters (but thee Antonio)
Would have beene kickt on to that damned enterpriſe?
That I had patience; me thinks thou ſhouldſt not
Be the Villaine yet, report does ſpeake thee.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Nay gentle friend.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Tis true, 'tis true.
Had any 'twixt the North and Southerne Pole
Spoke theſe words but hee, it had not beene,
And he had falſely lyed.
This is a Creature I have rais'd, reviv'd,
Snatch'd from deſtructions teeth,
Incorporated to me, ſo deare and juſt, as not
A thing in all the world can be more truer to it ſelfe
And certaine: but his modeſty conceales it,
Could write a Volume of their loath'd deſignes,
And curſe the ſtories cauſe. O falſe Cornelia!

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Remember what you are.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Remembrance burſt!
There's no contemplation, nothing what ere can
Drive the thought of ſhame out of my mind:
Would I had never knowne diſcretion,
Could never have made diſtinctions of perſons,
And harmleſſe Creatures; hence forth be ignorance:
Mother of Nations and Vnderſtanding periſh:
Faire, foule Cornelia. The blue fac'd
Occan, nor her fertile wombe, that yields
Vs all increaſe, nouriſhes none ſo falſe as woman:
Traytors have they been ſince their firſt being,
And betray'd poore man e're he beheld himſelfe.
Cornelia can it be thou art a Strumpet?
Oh, oh, fury finiſh that, burnes thee to Cynders.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Worke on, worke on:
Fate lifts me to the ſeat of my deſires;
And I am proſperous and happy.
This Devill jealouſie, my preſent friend,
Cannot at leaſt but quite ſupplant Anthonio:
Beſides this ſeeming honeſty of mine, begets me good
Opinion of Franſcicus, as ſhall inſtall my wiſh;
All addes to my availe: what need I curſes feare
For the debate my policy ſhall raiſe betwixt theſe Turtles▪
I hold with Machievel, for fame or profit
To breake oath or league with friend,
Or Brother: there's nothing gainfull bad:
I ha my wiſh, Advancement now
Is what I aime at, preſent glory here:
He's true religious, that does nothing feare.

div.stage: Enter Thomaſo, Valentius, Lodwicks, Stultiſſimo, and Fub.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: And how? and how?
Was it not patheticall and pretty?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Y faith I never heard the like.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: I thanke the Muſes, I have as ſharpe a conceite of mine owne when I liſt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Sir I take you to be a great devourer of Verjuyce.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Now and then; but 'tis not altogether that; every one has his gift.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Tis ſo.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: Some has two or three.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: You ſay true Signior, ſome has twenty: for which they may thanke impudency and the art of begging.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: The art of begging: pray you how long has begging beene an art?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Ever ſince in rid in a foote-cloath, and wore the badge of authority.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: How long's that agoe?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Ever ſince you Grannams daughter had a Calfe of your age.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: Is't poſſible?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes, and will continue till hee's a Bull and horne mad.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: Moſt miraculous: would I were mercinary, and had no more in me than an ordinary man: Signior, I crye you mercy. How doe you ſince you powred the pottle of wine in my neck, and threw the pot at my head, becauſe I would not pay my part o'th ſhot?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Was there ſuch a time?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Was there? Why have you forgot how you kickt me, and I crept under the Table: Ile be ſworne this Hip's as lame ever ſince, as if I had the Cyatica.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Abſurd and groſſe.

sp.speaker: Vallen.
sp.p: We muſt leave you Signior.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: I thanke you with all my heart: I am going to the foreſaid place: here's my ſervant Fub can tell you if I lye in my throat.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: I will aſſure you he's wandring to Puſſe, or as a man would ſay, to deale with Miſtris Clariflora.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: Yes faith am I: ſhe beat me tother day, and I am now going to make her amends. I thinke I endure more beating than any three in Venice.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Than a Stock-fiſh.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſigne you are offenſive.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: So they ſay that do't. Yeſter night a ſcurvy boy did ſo joule my head and the wall together, for holding opinion that Cheeſe was unwholſome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No more good Signior: farewell.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: At your ſervice:
Shall we expect you at the old houſe?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If you pleaſe:
Have you heard the like?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Theſe are Aſſes ſo tedious—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: They're kin to Burs, they will not off with ſhaking.
Now my Thomaſo what I have to ſay:
The chiefe occaſion made me ſummon you,
Is to entreate your knowledge and aſſiſtance
In ſuch a project, (as your ſelfe ſet by) and him that muſt
Partake in the attempt, Venice in Italy
Conceales the man that I durſt credit.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Let it not touch confuſion of the State,
Treaſon, and Murther: whatſoe're it be,
Command my will and ſufferance.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Defend that ever I ſhould be ſuch:
Vallentius never had ſo foule a thought,
To infect himſelfe, and others.
Thus, in briefe, I love a woman; fairer
Than her ſelfe ne're wore the Epethite:
You have ſeene her ſure, and know her:
She's wife to Vanderman.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Correma's daughter?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That ſame onely wight, is the moſt precious
Beauty I adore, and would faine call mine own.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Knew you her husband?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: By his name, no further;
By that knowledge you underſtand his courſe.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Yes he's a Phyſitian: and beſides,
What elſe report ſpeaks of him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Liſten then my purpoſe,
The ſevere ſir, whoſe high ſtretcht phraſes
Galls the eares of Patience, and wiſedom would fain ſhun,
Beares ſuch a jealous and obſervant eye
Over the prey I aime at, all conference is debar'd,
And you may ſooner whiſper with the Saint
Argos had charge of, than converſe with her,
Vnſeene, and unſuſpected.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Is there no device to compaſſe her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But one, and this is it;
Your ſelfe and Lodwicke (harken I beſeech you)
Shall to this skilfull Vanderman preſent me
As one diſtracted: nay ſmile anon,
And with a kinde of ſober modeſty, as if you liſt you can,
Report ſome probable poſſibility, how
And which way I got my extaſie:
Let me alone to make your words ſeeme truth,
And ſo poſſeſſe my prating Mountebanke,
That he ſhall ſay and ſweare I'me mad at leaſt.
If not paſt all recovery.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Will this doe?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This, or none.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Then none.
Why this is the ſhalloweſt, indirecteſt courſe to win a woman that ever was compos'd, in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: In your opinion: why ſir?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Why, hope you to gaine her thus with a mad fit: marke the event, this is a courſe as wide: Are you ſo ſimple to imagine, ſhe a timerous woman, will endure your preſence, ſeeming poſſeſt? for ſhame believe it not, invent ſome other meanes.

sp.speaker: Lodw.
sp.l: I verily thinke ſo too, but he will never bee perſwaded.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: This were a way to ſcare her, and to make her ſhun you.

sp.speaker: Lodw.
sp.l: Leav't off, leav't off, and ſtudy ſome other new paſſage.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Doe, doe; this is the groſſeſt: fie Vallentius:

sp.speaker: Lodw.
sp.l: Come, you ſhall pardon him once: wee all miſſe ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Good gallants doe not ride me, leſt I gall you: Ile aſſure you I trot hard: why my brace of conceits, my wits; what does your abundance of wit runne at waſte: for ſhame, have you ſo poore a braine, and you my moſt exquiſite excellent,
for ſhame take off your ſpectacles and ſee better: are you ſuch a dunce: are you ſo rare a Coxcombe, to deeme I will appeare alwaies the ſame: are you the men you promiſt? will you be Maſters of your words and oaths, tender your vow'd aſſiſtances?

sp.speaker: Lodw.
sp.l: I am Lodwicke ſtill.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: And I Tomaſo.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Continue ſo: what ſhall redound upon this adventure, falls upon my head, be it no ſhame to yours: onely preferment and your ſmooth apologies.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Leave that to us.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: But can you act the mad-man bravely?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Tut, I have play'd Ajax, and perform'd the part wel, to make boaſt of imitation, better than he that Lucian writes of, who ſo digeſted what he plaid, that he run mad indeed.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Can you do't?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: So well, as Aeſop could diſcharge his Scene, whereby he won moſt laud.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: This praiſe were well in me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Miſtruſt not my behaviour, and if it prove not correſpondent to my word, thinke me an idle vanter, and no meet aſſociate for you.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: When put we this in practice?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: There's no deferring weekes, nor dayes, this houre, this very evening does my fit begin.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Shall we about it then?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What elſe, what elſe? Remember gentlemen you fall not upon the ſcandall of Ignorance: but in any caſe keep your countenances.

sp.speaker: Lodw.
sp.l: Make no doubt of that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come then, and fortune friend us.

div.stage: Enter Franciſco, and Antonio, as in a Grove.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Draw your ſword.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Gainſt whom?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Gainſt me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Gainſt any living man thats your enemy:
What ailes my deare Franciſco?
By your face you ſhould not be in health.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Draw your ſword.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What meane you?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Draw your ſword.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Gainſt you never in anger:
Are you well Franciſcus? me thinkes your cheeke
Carries a paler hue than wont to be his Livery.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I muſt fight with you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: With me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: With thee perfideous monſter, with thee thou Iudas.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are you your ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Thou haſt abuſed me, wronged me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I wrong'd and abus'd you?
Franciſcus, can you think ſo of me?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Doe not enquire; yonder he ſits knowes all:
Look yonder, thou art to him tranſparent, and ſeen through,
As eaſie as the aire: doe not cloak thy vice, doe not:
See'ſt thou this? ſee'ſt thou the place we tread on?
Marke my ſpeech, one of us twaine, or both (never ſtart)
On this cold earth, this very Champion, ſhall
Offer up a crimſon ſacrifice of his moſt precious blood:
For that cauſe drew I to this ſilent ſhade,
Remote from all ſuſpition, where
Revenge might glut with ſatisfaction:
Draw thy ſword, or elſe thou never ſhalt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Did not my love prohibit,
Thinke, Franciſco, I could not be a Coward,
Nor endure the opprobrious taunts the malice
Of your heart has made your tongue throw on me;
Why I know not: believe me, and receive it for a truth,
Were you ſome other, in this wide vaſt world,
And not Franciſcus, you had beene a dogge
That I had kickt long ſince; but you are my friend,
And my diſgrace is buried: yet if you carry honour
In your breaſt, and beare your wonted venerable mind,
Make me to underſtand from whence, or why your
Comminations & undecent language point thus at me alone?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Will you draw?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Do you thirſt for bloud? if ſo, and mine, hide to the hilts your naked inſtrument, my boſome is your mark: thruſt home and take your fill.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Will you draw?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You had mine anſwer, never▪ never.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Do you not love my wife?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, by Heaven.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Confeſſe, ô impudence! my wrong cryes out, no more expoſtulation, remember Iulio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Wherefore him, he is a Toad more virulent, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Bathe there, adulterate fiend, and thy red drops waſh off thy guilty ſtains.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh, ſome charitable creaure!
Franciſco, dear Franciſco.
No pittie, no remorſe, I bleed, and much effuſion robs me of my breath, ſomething of ſence relieve me, help, ô help.

sp.speaker: Shep.
sp.p: That dying tune, was ſure a mans, where art thou friend, ſpeak thou that cryd'ſt for help, if thou wouldſt have thy wiſh, ſpeak once again: where art thou?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Shep.
sp.l: To one in thy caſe could I nere leſſe wiſh, then health and mercy, how fare you ſir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh! Oh!

sp.speaker: Shep.
sp.p: His utterance is decayed, and life begins to creep out of his wounds: let me ſee, ſo many, and ſo mortall! can I but ſtay the courſe I wiſh no more: have I nothing left, to ſtay this paſſage: well, yet ſtill hee breathes, that I had here ſome help. Thy aid Omnipotent, yet his pulſes beat, life is not quite diſcharged,—no ſuccour! keep he but motion, till I can beare him to my Cell, I doubt not, his recovery: this winde, this winde, that my Balmes were here: for my youthfull dayes heaven lend ability.

div.stage: Enter Criſſippus, Tomaſo, Lod wick, Iulio, Cornelia, and Phemone.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Run to all brief confuſion.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Good, ſir, be pacified.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: Even in the pride, and noon time of his fortunes, brought to deſtruction thus: a milder, better tempered Gentleman, Venice nor Europe yielded; his knowledge made me proude, and I was rich in his adoption.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: O my Franciſcus, ô my gentle Lord!

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: My brother, my deare brother.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.p: My ſonne, my ſonne, ſo noble, valiant, wiſe, dearer to me then him I call mine owne by true ſucceſſion, doe you weep?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: I am not bleſt, all things doe ſort contrary; 'twill not do, my projects thrive not, would I had been ſilent, wee know the firſt, but not the laſt, I begin to perceive our policies of times whets the Axe, cuts off our own necks; I have and one my ſelfe, that it ſhould come to this, wee ſeeke to mend ſo long, that we marre all: for mine own part, would I could have been content: but who would have dreamt the courſe would have proved ſo violent: well this I am ſure on, I may ſtarve ere I get ſuch another friend.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Siſter, if it be true, as ſo the rumour goes, you have playd falſe, and wronged your deareſt friend: you are not worthy ſuch another man, you ſole Queene of Africk; had you to live as many ample yeares as our firſt fathers, or their ages thrice: you might ſpend all thoſe tedious houſes twice told, ere you finde a Mate ſo worthy, were you equivalent, in birth and beauty, and had no paralell: Neptunes gems to boot, you want worth and excellencie both, to weigh down his demerit; Vertue and Honour ſtampt him for their own, at his firſt being, and the Graces ſtrove to increaſe his plenitude. More perfection then he has, hee needs not, where ere he's betook.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Somthing that's mighty, ſtain me Leopard like, if ere I gave offence.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: I ſhould be loath to wiſh ſo.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Not you offend? look here,
This letter left he as a teſtimony,
Who is there here 'mongſt all this company,
That knew Franciſcus, knew not he affected,
And highly priz'd the ſlain Antonio?
What could have rais'd ſuch deadly enmity?
But this, but this, thou ſtrumpet,
Between ſuch twinlike friends?
Thy miſdemeanour, thy approved falſneſſe;
Which too, too well he knew▪
Thou haſt und one him,
Fled he is and gone;
His goods already ſeiz'd are for the State:
And die he ſhall if ever he be took,
Oh, fie upon thee my perpetuall ſhame!

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Can you this behold, you upright Juſtices?

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Thou art not mine, I here deny thy claime,
And warn thee hence-forth,
Come not neere my roofe:
Pine, ſtarve and die, reliefe and comfort
Never more expect from him that was thy father.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing I ſee, to work the diſſolution of a houſe,
How eaſily this is done?

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: I muſt weep, to deeme
I ſhould be forc'd to be ſo cruell;
More I have to ſay, if teares would let me;
(Me thinks) I could both kiſſe and curſe her:
If ſhe be wrong'd, and through ſome make-ſtrife,
Theſe foule ills prove a greater plague,
Then fell in Egypt, light on the Authors head,
The maws of Dogs be his Tombe:
Help me to curſe him Iulio.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Ten thouſand ſwords ſtrook me together.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Liv'd there ſuch a wretch,
And that I knew him,
Let my faith not ſave me,
But I would teare the Viper with my teeth,
And like a rude and ſavage Caniball,
Eate out his treacherous heart.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Now the foule Devill, ſtuffe thy glutnous paunch,
I am no viand for thee?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Who's this comes here, Arbaces?

div.stage: Enter Arbaces, with two or three Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Diſgrace and woe ſmite all this company, and make them feele my griefe.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Diſgrace, contagion, and what can be worſe,
Smite thee and all thy tribe.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Undone, undone, where is Anthonio?
Where's my ſonne Criſippus?

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Anſwer thine own words;
Where's mine Arbaces?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Where ſuch a Villain—
And fell murtherer ſhould.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: More charity for ſhame.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Sorrow gripe my heart till it be bloud leſſe,
But what thou ſpeak'ſt is falſe:
A more ſlanderous lye never left the lips of any.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Lye?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Sir, be perſwaded.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Tell not me, Ile prove it on him, Arbaces, boy—

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: That we were alone.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well ſaid, old Lad.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Shew thy ſelf a man, meet me to morrow.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Good, ſir, forbeare.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Not meet him.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Will you be entreated?

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Give me leave.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Will you be pacified?

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Meet thee, yes I will meet thee;
I dare meet a man: Arbaces thou ſhalt finde it.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Come, you are a prater.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Prate; ye ſhall heare from me.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: With reverence of your age, good ſir,
You want of that diſcretion and ſtayd judgement;
Your yeares and place requires: It is not well,
One of your reputation and report,
Should ſo forget your ſelf: to be plain,
You lack advice; and this ſame cavillation,
Meerly provok'd by you.
Proclaymes a loud your inconſiderate folly.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Sir, ſir; check your own:—
You never loſt a ſonne, and cannot
Ayme at my affections and paternall care:
You have undone me—
Robb'd me of my joy.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: You are not right conſiderate,
Who has undone you ſir?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: You, you, and ſhee, and every one of you;
The puniſhment for murder fall on all your heads,
And blaſt your terrene hopes:
Cruell, cruell, butchery.
Waſt not ſufficient that he took his life,
As by his own confeſſion:
Undid his wofull mother and my ſelf,
But he muſt practice more
Immanly, more dire auſterity;
Throwing his breathleſſe trunk
In ſome obſcure night-ſhaded Manſion,
A prey for ravenous beaſts;
Where never eye of creature rationall,
Shall more behold him: unchriſtian part,
If there be juſtice, above or here;
As certainly there's both: Ile petition,
My lowd complaints ſhall pierce both ſides o'the globe,
And ſtrike a ſorrow in the rudeſt thing,
Nature for mans uſe moulded:
O! my Antonio? my joy, my life;
My deare, my deare Antonio.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: There's cauſe for this.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Sure, ſure, how fond was I
That could not weigh this before;
Having his proper cauſe,
If for ſome not ſlaughtred,
Nor mine own, but by ſelection,
I could ſigh my age, ſhed flouds of teares,
Meet dangers in my ſhirt, bid conquering
Death defiance, if all this and more I durſt attempt,
For one no otherwiſe, then mine by law;
Needs muſt he rave paſt rules of Manhood,
And forget all precepts that ſupport his ſuffrance:
See you this? What think you of your ſelf?
Have you not done well? account thou ſcandall,
That like the Whore of Greece,
Was teem'd for mans deſtruction;
Thy ſin upon thy ſelf, my doore is ſhut;
That hoſpitality I ſhew a ſtranger,
Shall be reſtrained from thee.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Moſt courteous ſir,—expect more.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Keep your Oriſons to charm relenting beggers.
Such in need, as may thy wants relieve;
Or at leaſt ſympathy thy mournfull tale,
When fierce diſtreſſe ſmiles,
Expect more comfort from the bluſtring North,
When he does blow the higheſt Acorn head
Down to the Medow, and there dips his cup;
Then leaſt relief from me, for thee;
For thee chaſt Maid, all beniſons,
And goodneſſe, that I can, command and have.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Your liberality was ever ſuch,
As merits more then thanks; yet thus far,
Truth emboldens me to ſay you are too cruell kinde,
Not all the proofs,
What ere incenſt my brother to his rage;
Can wean me to that vain opinion,
To think it her deſert: I dare proteſt for her,
No perſwaſion can drive belief in me,
To call Antonio falſe; if you prove ſo cruell,
So unnaturall as you ſpeak, there is no pitty in you:
Nor are you ſuch as a father ought to be,
Thruſt her out, then turn me off;
If you ſupplant one, you extirp us both,
And her extreams are mine.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Since you diſdain my proffer'd courteſie,
Together ſhelter your neceſſities;
Take up your habour with the hardy beaſt;
Theſe gates are lockt to her and her relievers
Hence-forth I will forget her,
Blot her name forth of the Bed roule
Where my children ſtand,
And vow I had none ſuch:
Hence, hence, thou ſcandall.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Thus guilt leſſe ones, ſuffer the guilties blame,
While they triumph in fraude, thus the ſtrict Judge
Condemnes th'innocent for the thieves offence;
Whilſt partiality allows his wrong,
And greatneſſe makes it good;
Will equity never take place again?
Has truſt left ſwaying here? that I but knew my crime:
Or that Franciſco but beheld my heart!
Let mine eyes rain a river of ſalt drops,
And my tears drown me, if any foule ſin of mine,
Deſerve Franciſcoes hate:
I had rather heaven had made me any thing,
Then one ſo much unhappy,
When ere thou bideſt on the plenteous ſhore,
Or labouring floud,
Proſperity adhere to thy proceedings,
And fame conclude thy deeds,
For me deſpiſed, ſuch be my fortune as my loyalty,
And I requeſt no more,
My ſweet, my ſweet Franciſco.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Heaven do thee right.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And if thou beeſt not honeſt,
There's neither pride nor coozenage in this Citie:
If every conſcience were well ſearcht,
And you did not finde
Some dainty fine conceited Rogue
Has been tempering,
Let me return to my Cradle,
And be hang'd in my ſwadling clouts.

div.head: Actus tertius. Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter Vallentius, and Doctors Wife, Lodowick, Tomaſo, and Julio.

sp.speaker: Tomaſo.
sp.p: THink you it ſo?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes, and verily believe't.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Tis ſtrangly carried.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Mark the end, marke the end;
Why do you ſigh, Signior?
Are you troubled with the Crampe?

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: O, blame him not, he has good cauſe to ſigh,
Franciſco ſet by him precious: How fare you, Signior?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Never worſe, my Friend's undone.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
I, a miſchiefe and a vengeance oth' cauſe, by this ſword, nay, feare not man, I am not angry, and I could not judge, well, I ſay no more: but if hee did not walke on
Stilts, I do deteſt eating and drinking, and thoſe are two neceſſaries, a man can hardly live well without them.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: The very Paragon, mirrour of the time.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: If I could not have wept when I beheld her, and that was more then I did at the death of my father, I have no beliefe in me.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Who but ſhe, the wonder of our age.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No more words, mark the end, marke the end; I ſay, ſtill mark the end.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: I muſt leave you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Not as the wench left the Frenchman in the ſuds, there's neither mettle nor ſociety in thee; if thou abandon'ſt my company, till we have viſited Valentius.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: I wonder how he ſpeeds?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Did he not act the madman to the life, was't not wel? could ever a Dunſticall Doctor in this Towne, have pickt falſhood out of his behaviour: he was ſo mutable, ſo full of varying tricks (me thinks) I ſee him yet.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Defer your viſitation till to morrow, or late ſometime to night: I am yet unfit, this ſudden trouble has made me not my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay, you muſt goe; I have ſworne you ſhall, and (that preſently.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: I pray you pardon me,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I will not be deny'd, refuſe me now and ever.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Youle have your humour ſtill?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What, eſchew acquaintanceſhip? forget, After my moſt hearty commendations, my very truſty friend, 'Twere ſin and ſhame Tomaſo.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: But ſome other time.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: This time, ſometime, other times, and all times, this day, yeſterſtay, tother day, and every day; no houre amiſſe, march on, march on.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p:
I could launch my Dagger through my ſide, at one eaſie throw: begger my friend; ſubvert mine owne eſtate, and undo her, by whom I hope to climbe, accurſed, brainles ſlave: could the damn'd Devill with all his fire-brands, beat into my pate no ſounder ſubtilty. I had, I had reliefe, Foole
vaunt of that?▪ boaſt what thou hadſt? or might have? tis paſt, 'tis gone, my villaine ſelfe, confounded has my ſelfe, and him that did ſuſtaine me:
sp.l: What choaks Corne ſooner than ſide-fed weeds,
Who ofter does man wrong than he afeeds:
Let me ponder; have I no other invention?
No trick to take away my life, after my meanes:
Study upon't, I'me ſtrooke upon a ſand,
Swallow'd, devowr'd, through wilfull ignorance,
Never to riſe againe: 'tis a villaines caſt,
Firſt to ſinke others, them himſelfe at laſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You cannot blame me neither:
For love himſelfe undertooke more for love;
Had you been tangled in a Labyrinth more intricate
Than held the Minataure, or have beene
By Inchantments bound to ſervitude,
My life's adventure had my love expreſt,
And offered the releaſe.

sp.speaker: Doct. wife.
sp.l: Our plighted amities will dwell in me
While life endures; the many winters, & the tedious hours
We two have ſpent alone, alone Vallentius,
When nothing but what was not fit the Sunne
Should look upon,—Alacke my Husband.

div.stage: Enter Doctor, Thomaſo, Lod wicke, Stultiſſimo, and Fub.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It muſt not be denyed, Ile maintaine't before the Synod, here's my witneſſe: was't not well done of brave Caligula to make his horſe a Senator? deny't, deny't, would not a good horſe ſhew well among a teame of Aſſes: ha, what thinke you: give me another ſword: O noble Hector, looke, Achilles flyes, and bloody Pyrrhus ſhrinkes.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Alas, alas.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What newes, what newes?

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: Gentlemen he takes me for a Carrier:
You are deceived ſir, I am not the party.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Will Pluto keep his word, ſhall all extortioners, engrocers, uſurers, be finely damn'd, of what kind ſoe're? will he ſpare none?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Wondrouſly ſpent.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Let me ſee, let me ſee, the ſonne of Panace, a ſprightly Lad; Hercules, a luſty youth, a very luſty youth; Sampſon, a tall young man, a very tall young man.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Does he not do't well?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ile make thee proov't, Ile make thee proov't.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: I thinke you are mad:
What ſhall I prove?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why greateſt generalls, that command whole Legions, and traine, and keepe in order every man, cannot keepe in a woman.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: That's an eaſie queſtion, becauſe moſt of them get Follies wings, and grow ſo light there's no ho with them: they muſt flye out.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Hang them, they are naught all: Tell not me learned Ovidius Naſo, what's your name.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Good ſir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That bloody villaine: Treaſon gentlemen, call up a Guard, the traytor's diſcovered: binde him ſure, ſure: are you tooke napping ſirrah: Downe with him, downe with him, downe.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Helpe, helpe, helpe Gentlemen.

div.stage: Vallentius beates him in, the gentlemen would come between. Exit all but the Doctors wife.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: I doe not like this.

div.stage: Enter Valentius againe, and kiſſes her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now my ſweet I have ſent him off in poſt,
Let us retire the while.
Who in affection will not his wits prove,
Was never loyall, nor did ever love.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p:
Paſt, paſt cure, I doubt. Give me leave, I finde by
my Art 'tis no Vertiga, no whirling, but a meere ſetled frenzy: Nay I pray you give me leave: for as both Hypocrates, and Gallen, Avicen, Podalirius, Rucis, Cornelius, Celſus, Corannus, Augustino, and Rombart, doe you conceive mee? beſides a dozen or two of Engliſh-men, moſt learned and worthy phyſitians (if I knew what they were) have demonſtrated paraphraſtically, both it and the cauſe, ſtyling the malady the digeſtion of the braine, or Irrevocabilis ignis, the irrevocable fire: Nay, will you underſtand me?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Would we could.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I pray you give me leave.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Who hinders him?

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: Sir if you can ſpeake our tongue, I would very faine be beholding to you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Art thou mad?

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: Not altogether mad, though I confeſſe I have beene prickt with the thornes of Love: I have beene over ſhooes in my dayes.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Avoydance, for charity avoydance.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: Yes marry ſhall you: I would deſire you to helpe me to a pill, or a potion that could make one honeſt, that I doubt is a little gone aſtray.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Avaunt, avaunt.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: No ſir, ſhe is none of my naunts: ſhee's one that muſt be my wife.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Turbulant fiend: avaunt, avaunt I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: I would have it applyed ſir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Illiterate dunce, abandon my houſe, avaunt I ſay againe.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.p: Nay, I pray you be quiet, for though I have endured many hard words at your hands, I ſhall hardly brooke blowes.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Good gentlemen give me leave to laugh: ha, ha, ha, the Doctors wife, and the Mad-man: the mad-man, and the Doctors wife.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Why ſir, the fits upon him, and he's upon her, and younder's ſuch ſport, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Fire and Thunder.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Runne: ware hornes.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Is this true ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Follow the Doctor, believe your eyes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Beware the trap Valentius.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Pray heaven he be not tane with nibbing.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why are you melancholy Signior?

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: Faith ſir I' me troubled with cornes, and ever againſt raine they make me ſo melancholy—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Is that it, for the thing you ſpake on, you ſhall not be beholding to the ſcald peremptory Doctor: Come to my Chamber anon, and Ile give you a powder ſhall fulfill your requeſt, as well as all the potions or Pills he can deviſe.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Nay, but will you be conſtant.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Say no more:

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: And you doe take my word, while I live: She and I will be at your ſervice: when ſhall I come for't?

sp.speaker: Lod
sp.l: Any time after noone. Will you walk Tomaſo?

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: This is good newes withall my heart: Fub we are all made; thou ſhalt have a new Livery out of the bargaine.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: I thanke you ſir, I would I had it.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt, thats as good: would I were whipt but I could be monſtrous merry now.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: No I pray you bee not monſtrous merry till you are married.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: Ile goe give thee a pottle of Sack.

lg.head: The Taverne Sceane.
lg.l: And ever he gave her a bob,
And ever he gave her a blow:
But where he knockt her once above,
He thumpt her thrice below.

sp.l: What wil't not doe? prethee-let's be luſty.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: As a Crow in a Gutter. Run there ſhe goes.

div.stage: Enter Antonio, and the old ſhepheard diſguiſed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Father, for ſo I muſt ſtile you,
Your care and paines in my recovery,
Deſerves a recompence more than I am able to performe:
Now I conſider with my ſelfe, had we compaſſionate ſoules,
Or were men but good, they would baniſh beggery
The World quite over, and every one have ſufficient.
As hitherto you have conceald my courſe,
Continue ſtill your wonted ſecreſie,
Call me your ſonne, and ſuch appoyntments as a father
Should command me to endure I ſhall performe:
Bleſſed, bleſſed be you: effectuall be my prayers.

sp.speaker: Shep.
sp.l: The longer time you ſo journe here with me
The more welcome: nothing more I crave;
But if I dye while you recide i'th' grove,
Out of your charity you'le take the paines
To lay me in the grave I have prepar'd, and with your hand,
Your foote, or any thing, caſt duſt upon my body,
And ſpend a little Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: More than this I will, and more than I will ſpeak.
Franciſco, wherſoe're thou bideſt, abide in quiet,
And have my pardon ever. If thou be'ſt fled
For any cauſe of mine, and I thy ruine prove,
Defend it heaveu, were't not for triall of Phemone's love,
And promis'd conſtancy, how ſoone would I renounce
My habitatiation, uncloath thy feare, & ſet all even againe?
Nothing 'mazes, nor drives me into that ſerious
Contemplation, as whence his wrath ſhould proceed.
Perchance Franciſcus thinkes me unfit to call him brother,
And his ſud daine rage proceeded from advice.
If it be ſo for ever will I keep this ſhady bower,
And never hold companionſhip with man,
More than is preſent, forget Arbaces ever
Cal'd me his, or that I was his ſonne.
Circle me ſafety, what are theſe come here
Where never neighbourd welt?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Calamity could not inflict ſo much as I could beare
With patienee, did Franciſcus imagine but the truth:
No lenity, but all extreames that may
Attend me with their ſharpeſt violence,
If e're I broke my vow: this ſorrow,
Nor the haviour I ſuſtaine are for mine owne endurings,
Witneſſe you that know all ſecrets, 'tis for him
I wiſh thrice better than my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, and that Cornelia; as ſure as the black Ouſell
Has a yellow mouth, that whiſtles me awake.
Tis ſhe, or I am fond.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: O my Franciſcus! O my deareſt Lord!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There needs no more for confirmation:
What make they here? Doe not undoe me wonder.
Ne're had two ragged coats more orient pearles,
Than you two ſhells doe hide: 'tis ſhe, or I am fond,
Leap not forth with joy, ſuch needy robes
Should wrap the ſhoulders of neceſſity,
When winter falls the Leafe: happy Antonio,
I am diſguiſed, and ſo, if that my ſpeech reveale not,
Without ſuſpect I may obtaine my wiſh,
And have all doubts reſolv'd: Ile greet 'em.
Bonny wight, what e're you be,
Lucke be in your company:
Are you Sylvanus, ſay to me?

sp.speaker: Phem.
sp.l: None ſuch, good Shepheard.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Deft and trim ones mickle glee,
Be you what you pleaſe to be,
Some diſaſter tend by yee,

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Never, never more.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: A me unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Welladay, now by my Creed,
And my merry Oaten Reed,
Sike another rouſing ſigh
Would well ſplit me gay and blith:
Let a loutiſh Clowne partake,
Why this ſobbing dole you make?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: O inconſtant world.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: A me unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Wonderment of woe relate
If ſimpleneſſe you might not ſcorne,
How you hapt to be forlorne.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: The ſtory would be too tedious for the time,
And would undoe the ſpeaker: Friend no more,
You ſhall doe well to leave us.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Be not all too keene, bright ſtarre,
If my pertneſſe went too farre,
Mercy is the doome I ſue,
Good things never meant more true,
Than the ſilly ſhepheard did,
Late wen he your ſorrow bid:
Diſcourſe the meanes merry Pan,
And the ſageſt gods doe ſcan;
Wherefore was it? well a neare,
You foule mucky cloud I feare
Will be ſprint us, Poebus twaine,
If ſo liſt you but to daine
A poore ſhepheards entertaine,
Welcome ſhould you be, I wiſſe,
Nor thing comely ſhould you miſſe,
Though not courtly: anſwer make,
Will you my ſmall feaſting take?

sp.speaker: Phem.
sp.l: The raine begins to fall;
Siſter accept the Shepheards courteſie,
His ſimpleneſſe cannot but meane well ſure.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Even what you pleaſe:
Whither I goe, or whereſoe're I reſt,
Sorrow with me, and I with ſorrow feaſt.
Welcome, welcome, welcome ſtill,
Never with a freer will
Was welcome ſpoken, by the skie;
Welcome, welcome heartily.
Alacke, alacke, the rotten ſouth
'Gins to ope his dewy mouth,
Time to hide you: Father meeke
Give kind welcome, I beſeeke,
To theſe white ones, bonny girles,
Welcommer than heaps of Pearles.

sp.speaker: Sheph.
sp.l: You ſee our Cave, and make as bold as welcome.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Receive my adorations Queene of chance, Thou never gav'ſt that jewell to that man, was halfe ſo wel eſteem'd; my hopes have their deſires, Phemone, bleſt ſucceſſe; nothing that's amiſſe, but I ſhall underſtand: diſguiſe I thanke thee, joy ties up my tongue, and will not let mee ſpeake; they part not ſoone.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What Angle of the Earth muſt be my grave?
The Sea and Sunne have bounds, and know their courſe,
The ſonnes of men have none:
Limitleſſe he wanders the forraigne deſarts,
And begets more wonders every houre:
The Chime that tells the laſt minuite of the night,
Chides but in vaine when every thing's a ſleepe;
So I in the relation of my woe, when no man hearkens,
Spend but idle breath, and never finde reliefe.
But for increaſe ſake, I could wiſh devoutly,
I never had knowne woman:
What comfort ever others reapt from them,
They have beene plagues to me: to note the difference,
They are ſuch things, nothing's more worſe, nor better;
To ſay truth, they are Angels, and Devils;
I will not curſe 'em, leſt I make them worſe
That needs no badneſſe, nor rip up their defects,
Leſt I ſpend all my after time of life in nothing elſe but that.
Iulio, the profit of my Oriſona be thine,
Where e're I ſpend 'em, upright conſtant man:
