Yet I am eas'd, in that I doe not beare my ſlaviſh yoake,
Cocker mine infamy, as many doe within our Venice gates:
Thanks to thee Iulio; Chaſtity, honour of women,
Whither art thou fled? that they are all ſo falſe
I muſt forget 'em, they will make me mad
To thinke of their abuſe: would I could learne
What inquiſition is made after me;
Some ſpeech of my concealement will report blab out,
That I may heare the danger does purſue me,
Though I adventure life, I will know more,
Or dye in the preſumption: I'le nearer to the City.

div.stage: Enter Lodwick, Tomaſo, Iulio, Stultiſſimo, Fub, the Whoore, and the Bawd.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: That's a good jeſt yfaith; Drawer, gives more Wine.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What's a good jeſt Signior?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: That none ſhould be honeſt but the valiant.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How's that? how's that?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Why my beetle-brow'd Hoſt ſweares 'tis impoſſible for any to be honeſt, that is not valiant.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: What ſaid he? What ſaid he?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: That none could be honeſt, that were not valiant.

sp.speaker: Tomd.
sp.l: O very good, very good: more Wine here, hee's packing, ſet out his hand.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And his foote too, ere I have done: where's this fellow? another Pottle ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Sir I thanke you for my powder, it gave her halfe a dozen of tickling ſtooles, ſhe has beene looſe ever ſince.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Give me your hand, here's even now to all the inviſible hornes i'th' City.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Forget not the Countrey, let it go round I pray you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: A health.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: You'le have reaſon to pledge this ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Will you come? to morrow is the day Ile aſſure you, for better or worſe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: To morrow from better to worſe?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Yes faith he has ſaid it, and I ſweare it, from better to worſe indeed.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Married to morrow Signior?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: You have ſaid we ſhall be doing.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Vndoing he meanes.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: So neare marrying Clariflora, and not acquaint your friend? yfaith I thought Miſtris you would have let me underſtood what had paſt.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: 'Tis my part to conceale.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: She were no good Bawd elſe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Come, ſit round, ſit round, to morrow the day?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Pardon me, Ile not ſit next this louſie fellow: gentlemen, what doe you with this poore rogue in your companies? Does he come to make mirth, can hee play the foole wittingly?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I know him not.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Would he were ſet downe ſtaires, I never could endure him from the firſt: Franciſcus made me know him.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Sirra, if you meane to depart in peace, begon ſuddainly.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Would the Aſſe could rid this intruding Copeſmate.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Let me beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: You ſhall goe, your prayers cannot ſave you; Fub, ſhew him the way downe.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Shall I be your Vſher? will you follow your leader ſir?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Thus poverty's deſpis'd at home, abroad, and in all companies.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: A whorſon Tatred-demallion, come amongſt Gentlemen of ſort. What, is't no more but up and ride? How now Fub, is he vaniſht?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: The Drawers have drawne him out Sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Clinke boyes.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Drinke boyes.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: And let the Cannikin clinke boyes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Stultus.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Yes Lodwick.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Tomaſo, ſhall's make a night on't mad lads?

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: And a mad night too Bullies: where ſhall's ſtrike faile?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
The Leaguer, where but a'th' new Leaguer: there's
generous entertainment for Gallants of ſort at all times: and for entrance truſt me my mates.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: But money grows low, and expences will flye high.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Fly hye, let it, I have a jacke in a boxe ſhall pay for all one day.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I am as full as a Spunge, I cannot ſinke up a drop more.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: No matter, we can ſqueeze ſome more out thus: we can wake the Conſtable, trouble the neighbours, diſquiet the Maſter and whole family, ſpill his Wine, puffe his Tobacco, foule his roomes, practiſe who ſhall breake moſt holes, and cleanlieſt, in the bottome of quart-pots, with a piece of a Tobacco-pipe: cry good morrow mine Hoſt, we ha' made a madde night on't I vow, and ſo trance; wee are no Gallants and we cannot doe this.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: But this courſe is either conſcionable, or commendable.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Faith 'tis the courſe, moſt of the corke-headed Candle-ſnuffes walke in theſe latter daies, late at nights.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well, let them reſt: So, ho, the Leaguer.

sp.speaker: Munk.
sp.l: Chi-va-lah.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Amice.

sp.speaker: Munk.
sp.l: The word.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Pecima largienda.

sp.speaker: Munk.
sp.l: Let 'em paſſe: downe with the Percullis:
Lights and attendance, welcome Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: I ever ſaid, it might come in a night, that came not in an age, Et ecce noctem faelicem; ſee, that joviall night is come: They have beene playing high, and potting deepe: Lights, Wine, and more ſtooles for theſe Gentlemen; welcome.

div.stage: Enter Lodowick, Tomaſo, Stultiſſimo, and Fub.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Tomaſo when's the day?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Aſſure's this the night before to morrow, I have brought in my Eſtate a matter of 400 pound per annum, in Deeds, Leaſes, Fee-ſimple, and Coppy-hold already: and that's no ſimple Eſtate youle ſay: I meane to bid you welcome to a Leaguer of mine own ſhortly Gentlemen; ſome wine you Scondrils.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I'me pleas'd to here't, whoſe faults this, yours Tomaſo?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: What's this Leaguer rayſed yet, Par la ho boy, I thought we ſhould have had a ſecond ſiege of Troy on't, is their Reckoning paid? not a penny, they call'd for one, but in ſuch a drunken key; I bad em ſleep upon't, and I would tell em more on't when they were ſober.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Beſt of all, and whats to pay then?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Nine and ſix pence, Sir, allowance for lights, linnen, coals to light faggots: and ſix pence for one journymans ſleep only deducted, and yet they grumbled too.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: But nine and ſix pence, and grumble; my friend the reckoning's not payd you ſay.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: Not a penny.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: The reckoning but nine and ſix pence, how poorely this ſhews, in a Leaguer too, and friends that pretended me a courteſie too? How many joynts of meat to ſupper?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Only a couple of clean Pipes, ſome three times fild I thinke.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: No meat, come to hanſell a Leaguer, what no meat? Are they abed at Anthonies Ordinary yet?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Two houres ago.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Step down, and ſee, nine and ſix pence, they muſt and ſhall heare more of this: we may go beg, or buy up all the, refuſe, broken bread and meat, ſcraps, offall, and garbage that Cooks ſhops, Shambles, Ordinaries, Entries, and Richmens dores afford; nine and ſix pence, if they do not heare more of this—

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Tis paſt that time of night; Charitie's bed, ſir, but if not.—

sp.speaker: Bread.
sp.l: Bread and meat for poore priſoners, Bread & meat.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: What doth that fellow cry?

sp.speaker: Bread.
sp.l: Bread and meat for the poor priſoners, bread & meat.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: For poore priſoners? as fit for my purpoſe, as a Conny for a Purſnet; here, take mony, buy his proviſion by the lumpe: if I had ſtudied for a fortune to fall upon me, I could not have had a fairer.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: Wilt thou victuall thy Leager with ſcraps, ſweet Chuck?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: No, my ſweet Monkie, I have further aymes then ſo, this broken meat and baggage offall, will I ſtrew in my Kitchin, Dreſſers, Hall, Entries, and every doore and drawwindow, and perſpicous places about the houſe: foule all the veſſell, three or foure times over, all to beſmeere the ruſtie ſpits and dripping-pans; breake all my broken glaſſes, beat the bottom out of my Cans: beat all my foul Tobacco-pipes, into fractions

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: And to what end all this?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Perlahay, My friends ſhall heare more of that in the reckoning: My ſweet Monkie, when the Drunkards ſhall wake, and ſee all theſe ruines, or rather remayns of a plentifull Leager: Oh, haſt thou no apprehenſion? Why, I tell thee, they cannot chooſe out of their generous bounties, but ſee all diſcharg'd?
sp.l: Within. A cup of ſix, Drawer.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Oh, the Leager begins to riſe! Come Monkie a few directions for you in private, give you attendance on the Leager; let em call for what they will, and want nothing they call for: only I will tell em no more of nine and ſixe pence in the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: But for the nine and ſix pence.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Monkie, you ſhall heare more of that anon, when they are ſober? why Drawer, Dog, Dunghil-raker; is the Leaguer dry? By and by, a cup of ſix into the low Leaguer, there.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: So, ho, the Leaguer.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: What do ye lack? by and by, do ye call Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: No, and I call'd a Gentleman, he would anſwer me, I call a Drawer goodman Raſcall, art thou one?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: For fault of a better, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Couldſt not ha ſaid ſo then? where's the Maſter of the Leaguet?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Parlahey Monkie, bene venu Gallants, com a ſtato Sigiores mio com I ſtato.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Marry the better for your entertainment; thanks, ſir.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Thank him, I ſcorn to thank him, Ile pay him, and be out of his debt: come, to pay? A reckoning Drawer.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: You Raſcall, who takes away here? here's a houſe beſtrewed with garbage and offall, as if the great Inqueſt had been feaſted, &c.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: As good men, to no mans diſprayſe be it ſpoken, where's a Bill?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Prethee knock us not down, afore our time; was this certain feaſt of our making? what a ſpoyle of Poultery has here been? Tom • ſo, I muſt be beholding to thee for this ordinary.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Some ſmall trifle Stultiſſimo, the Reckoning is thought to be.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: The Reckoning's very high, nine pound ſix ſhillings.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Nine pound ſix ſhillings, Parlahey, and yet I uſe you like Chriſtians too boyes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nine pound ſix ſhillings, how could wee foure devoure ſo much being halfe drunk when we came in?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Why there's the miſtery? you fall aſleep with meat in your mouthes, my Miſtris and I ſtood it out.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: Waſt not an excellent Swan-pie? Servant.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: As ere ſwam in Mil-dam.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nine pound ſix ſhillings, one lay out for all,
Come, your purſes Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: And you love me, let me have the credit at this time there's: ten pounds, give me the reſt again (ah, wee had the braveſt Marchpane, and Sugar-candy Cuſtard) or do not, let it run on towards fouling of linnen, and paying for ſawee: the reſt agen, or do—

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: I do not think but you are ſawſt pretty well already, for the Devill a bit of meat ſaw I, and yet all theſe ſcraps could not come of nothing.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: The Reckoning's paid to a haire, come let's withdraw (but while the Room be a little finificald.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Parlahey, welcome Gallants to the Leaguer ſtill: pleaſe you withdraw.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We accept it thankfully.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Whoſe fault's this yours Tomaſo?

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: There wants lap.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Throw downe the pottle pot, let's have a gallon more.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Wilt pleaſe you Gentlemen, to heare any Muſicke▪ and a good Song?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Very fain, a good one.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: What's your fellows, whoſe noyſe are you?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Ruberts noyſe, and pleaſe you?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Call your fellows, and ſtrip your tools.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Here's to you Signior.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: A brace of them if you love me.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Marry and ſhall.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Score a gallon of Claret in the Pomegranat.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: What Tim?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Maſter Fub I rejoyce to ſee you well.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You are not merry Gentlewomen, Miſtris Durable what, no mirth?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: And how iſt, how have you done this ſeven yeares, welcome again.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: As you ſee, in perfect memory, when ſhall wee ride the hogſheads?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Ha, do you remember that night, Ancient Thumps health overthrew mee, my Maſter goes out of Towne next weeke; yfaith and youle come, there's halfe a dozen good boys, weele be ſwingeing merry, will give him a craſh, old Will, Will be here?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: What Will?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Little Will of the Mitre. Oh, Maſter Fub, Sir, out Maid, that gave us the Neats Tongue is gone.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: See, ſee.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Some Sugar there?

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.p: Ha, ha, hum.

lg.l: In ample ſtories written tis,
Who list but for to minde it;
How loved Narciſſus?
Go look and you ſhall finde it.
This Eccho was a Nymph moſt chaſte,
A lack, the more the pitty▪
She ſhould be ſo, and ſhould not reape▪
What follows in my Ditty?
Narciſſus was but young, I wiſſe,
But yet of perfect feature,
And had enough to ſatisfie
A reaſonable creature.
His brawny limbes became his parts,
No one of ſence could blame them:
And ſo did ſomething elſe I trow,
Eccho knew how to name them.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: A vertuous piece of matter, Gentlemen, wee'le no more on't.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay, hold up, Signior.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Bid her hold up, feare not me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Come Gentlewomen, ſhall we have a dance? Tomaſo what ſay you?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: You prevented me.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: I thought it ſhould have been my motion?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Wherefore ring thoſe bels?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Bels, you are deceived, it is the clincking of pots.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I would have ſworn, it had been Coronation day.
Maſters, can you play us Gaſcoynes Whibling?

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.l: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Let's ha't.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Here lacks a couple, we cannot dance it.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Lack a couple, what ſerve Tim and I for?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Tis true, well remembred.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Truly, Maſter Fub, I cannot dance.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Truly, you ſhall learn then.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: I ſhall be willing to endevour.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Strike.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Ile throw the pot at his head that ſtrikes heere,
Whoſe that will ſtrike?

div.stage: Hee drinks all the while they dance.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Rare yfaith, give's more wine.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: What, Timothy?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: By and by.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Look to the Lion.

div.stage: He riſes and throws down the table.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Ile have my Galliard too

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: You ſpoyle all.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How does your head, ſweet heart?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Yes faith, and thank you too, what Rogue's he that turns the Room round? ſhall we not quench our thirſts before we part?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What elſe my ſweet Signior, this is your ſervant?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Good enough for a property, he will ſerve my turn, as well as a better, I ſhall but uſe his name: do you think I would marry the Coxcombe, but only for colour and feare of the Law? I'de ſee him bak'd firſt.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Tis wiſely done of you? and ſo my Goſſip Slight could ſay I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Boy, another quart, and bring a Reckoning. Here ſir.

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.l: Heaven keep your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: In honeſter company.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Fub, call for a Looking-glaſſe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Did you go the right way?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: It's a cup of neat wine, Ile aſſure—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Miſtris to your ſelf, and to our next meeting?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: What's to pay?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Nine and ſix pence, and you're welcome.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: How comes that to paſſe?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Here's ſeven groats Glaſſes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: No leſſe, Ile aſſure your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Come your mony, Signior—

div.stage: Let's take away and pay together.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Fub, diſcharge it Fub.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: Some lights, ſhew the Gentlemen.

div.stage: Enter and follow with a letter from Vallentius.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Fub, I am ene as full as a Toad.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Yes, ſir, but do not ſpit your venome.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Prethee give mee another ſip. I am as dry as a Cook.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: So I think.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: A pox a this Megrum.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What's here, I prethee marke Tomaſo: Lodwick, I have my deſire: fetch mee off ſpeedily, leſt I cure the Doctour? yours Vallentius, leſt I cure the Doctour.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: What ſhould he mean by this?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why, belike he has infuſed his fit into him, and the Phyſician's turn'd Patient?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: That's impoſſible?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: But for Ʋallentius.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: We muſt redeem him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What elſe.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Heyda, is the winde in that door?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: A link good Tim, a link.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Here's one ready, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Signior, good night.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Not a drop more yfaith.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Wee'le take our leaves.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: When ſhall we ſee you?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Somtime to morrow, if my father ſend not.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Good night Maſter Lodwick, good night good, ſir.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Good night Tim, remember Friday.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: I warrant you, forget not to bring Hugh, Welcome Gentlemen.

div.head: Actus quartus. Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter the Doctor and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: I Speak't in thunder once again, no more: thou Babylonian Strumpet, in thunder I command thee thou lump of ſinne, no more.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Have patience, ſir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I rore it in thy eares, once more aloud, no more: cannot I deale, but you muſt be applying, you muſt be tampering, you muſt miniſter: have you not Pils for Potions? do you not traffique? do not you exchange Merchant?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Good Vanderman.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Sorcereſſe, I defie thee, and thy deeds of darknes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Heare me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I have heard and ſeen too much, has hee not paid you ſoundly for your pains: no, has he popt you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You are deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: You ſay very true, I am deceived indeed, and Fub'd, and Guld, and Rid, and you are Rid too.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What meane you?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Here blow it abroad, there's horns enow to do't.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why are you thus impatient?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Dainty fine y faith, very dainty. Whore thou haſt made me monſtrous, and I may challenge Gyants: Yes, he ſhall be your mad-man; Doe you not like his fits, doe you not, doe you not?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: God morrow to you both.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Why ſhould this be?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How doe you ſir? how does your patient?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Are you not ſatisfied? am I a ſtale? muſt you have new-found Crochets?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Doe you heare me ſir: is he recovered▪

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Homo Armatus, a man armed.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Have you heard the like?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Me thinks 'tis excellent.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: And when, when ſhall he plant againe?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I wiſh you would underſtand me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Here's a fruitfull ſoyle.

sp.speaker: Tom:
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Sir, I will be heard, and underſtood:
Save you Lady:

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: More furies, might, and ſecreſie, whoredome and The every bring all to confuſion.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Would we had more of this: we'le ſee what will come of all.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I perceive Vallentius was i'th' right, he's madde indeede:

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Good Morrow Gentlemen: I have good newes for you; your friend is well.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Your tidings makes us happy, and gives us a moyetie of that content which nothing can doe more.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: I ſhall rejoyce to ſee him what hee was, and Maſter of that temper he commanded, when he did dare the vaunting Bajeſet for taxing his beliefe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Tomaſo, Lodwick.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Valentius.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: I am glad to ſee you once again your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You're welcome to your wits.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: When time and place ſhall ſerve, my wit ſhall thanke you I am ever bound to you ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Harke you Lodwick, are not we partly Bawds?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Faith in one kinde, we have a ſnatch that way.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: So I ſay partly.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe, partly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not remember you, have not that bad opinion, doe not think I can be one ſo falſe by this kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Sibylla.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Ay me, my husband.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Once again and part.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Sibylla.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Farewell, Valentius.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A thouſand take with thee.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: What, hungry ſtill Vallentius, that you caſt ſuch a greedy eye that way?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How iſt man? what in a trance?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And kinder far then faire.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What, ſhall we have a Pamphlet; that he begins to ſtudy? doe you heare Ʋalentiuss: here's a friend of yours would ſpeak with you, when you are at leiſure.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I crave your pardon Gentlemen, as I live ſhe is—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What's this to the purpoſe?

div.stage: Enter Julio, and the Mercer with his man.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You know my price: for the fineneſſe of the ſilke, the working of the ſtuffe, and the pleaſantneſſe of the colour, the whole ſtreet ſhall not afford you a better, Ile aſſure you tis died in grain.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: The better for him that ſhall wear it, nothing but what's in grain can pleaſe him: let mee ſee, I know not how my mony will reach: the Silkman hath emptied my pocket this morning, but you will bate nothing of your price?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I proteſt ſir, I cannot, and ſave by it, and I know you would not wiſh me to be a loſer.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: By no means, I would have every man to live & thrive by what he profeſſeth, it is mine owne caſe: let me ſee, I cannot make up the ſum, I pray you let one of your men ſtep over to the next lane: I lie there at the Barbers, Ile diſpatch him preſently.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: My ſervants are all buſie for the preſent, you ſee my ſhop is full of Cuſtomers, and every one ſtriveth who ſhall be firſt ſerved.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: And I am in haſte too, for I have ſent for my Tailor to meet me at my lodging, and I am loth to diſappoint him, becauſe I would have his opinion in the ſtuffe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I pray you, ſir, be expeditious, and my man ſhall be with you by that time you have told out the mony.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: I am much obliged to you as a ſtranger, I care not if I accept—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Diſpatch me that Cuſtomer quickly, and follow this Gentleman to his lodging: you heare where he lies.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Yes, at the next turning?

sp.speaker: Mercers man.
sp.l: Ile but fold up this boult of Sattin, and be with him inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Turne by the next lane, and thou ſhalt be ſure not to miſſe it, though thou findeſt not me, I have took ſufficient order and you ſhall be ſure to be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: We have many cheapners, but few buyers, many ſuch cuſtomers as this would make quick riddance.

sp.speaker: Mercers man.
sp.l: What comes the ſumme to, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Three yards of Sattin and a halfe at ſeventeene, eight yards of Pluſh at foure and twenty; nay, there are divers other parcels, the ſumme is ſoon caſt up: thou ſhalt have a note of all.

sp.speaker: Mercers man.
sp.l: And Ile but fold up theſe few boults lie looſe, and cleere the counter and be gone.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Be quick there.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: But thou muſt be ſecret.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: As your ſelf, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: A pretty handſome youth, and will be loath to diſcover himſelfe, being extreamly baſhfull, and will make it ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Leave him to me, Ile perſwade him that I knew him, ere I ſaw him.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Hee's my Kinſman, next Couſin German's by the Mothers ſide; now playing the Wag, as many youths will doe, you know it Barber.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Very well, it hath been many a good mans caſe.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: He hath got a clap.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Theſe claps are got by clapping.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: But for one thing, never ſhould it grieve mee, I feare it might go nere to ſpoile his marriage, which I would not for more than Ile ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: You ſhew your ſelf a Kinſman.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Now his exuſe will be (as I told thee he's extreamly baſhfull) to enquire for a Gentleman that owes his Maſter mony, to comply with the old Proverbe, Though his excuſe be draff, yet drinks his errand.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: And lotion muſt be uſed.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: As it ſhall ſeem beſt: but thinkſt thou hee'l endure it.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: 'Twill put him to ſome pain.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Which Ile not heare, my heart's ſo tender ore him: when he comes (as long hee will not ſtay) take him in charge, Thy pains ſhall be well paid, for doubt not but Ile come to the concluſion.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Very good, ſir?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: My hope is it will ſucceed according to my wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Make no doubt of that, ſir.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: If I had, I had not made choice of thee above any other.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: You are my friend indeed: and ſo I hope to keep you.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: I will withdraw for the preſent, and inſtantly return.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Now good ſpeed with you, good cuſtomers are thicke ſowed, and come up but thin. It is good to make much of them, when we have them. This ſhould be the patient, that he talked off.

sp.speaker: Mercers man.
sp.l: I come to ſeek a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: You do: that owes your Maſters mony.

sp.speaker: Mer. man.
sp.l: Very true, ſir, you know my errand then.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Before you came.

sp.speaker: Mer. man.
sp.l: The Gentleman belike hath told it you.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: He hath indeed.

sp.speaker: Mer. man.
sp.l: Is he within?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: But before he went, left order with me, you ſhould be diſpatcht.

sp.speaker: Mer. man.
sp.l: Then I ſhall find him as good as his word: he hath acquainted you with my occaſions.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Ile aſſure you that, and intends well towards you, I pray come neer into the withdrawing Room.

sp.speaker: Mer. man.
sp.l: Ile wait on you, pray know you what it comes too.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Yes youth, I know, wherfore you come: pray reſt you in that chaire, and Ile be for you preſently; be not aſhamed, you are not the firſt, nor ſhall be the laſt, that meet with theſe diſaſters: and now come, pray ſhew me your commodity.

sp.speaker: Mer. man.
sp.l: The commodity belongs, ſir, to my Maſter, 'twas not mine.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Are his in danger too? let him not feare, but if hee have not let it run too far, there may be helpe found: nay, come, will you ſhew?

sp.speaker: Mer. man.
sp.l: Mean you the note: there are the parcels ſent.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Theſe parcels may in time grow great, come, will you be ruled, the Gentleman your Kinſman, told mee before, how baſhfull you would be; and it becomes you well: but for your parcels, ſhew them in time: for if delay be long, that little which perhaps you ſhall have left, in time will come to nothing: your Kinſman's loth that you ſhould ſpoile your Marriage?

sp.speaker: Mer. man.
sp.p: Spoile my Marriage, ſpoile not my Maſters debt, Neither draw theſe fearfull tricks on me: I need them not, pay mee the mony that your friend hath left, Diſpatch mee ſo, for Kinſman I have none; And honeſt Barber finde ſome elſe to ſport with, make me none of your Guls?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: But I pray ſay.

sp.speaker: Mer. man.
sp.p: I ſay, pay me ſir, what's my due, & what by your confeſſion, your friend left, or bring me to the party, or commodity he late had of my Maſter, or Coine for't: you have confeſt him to be your friend, therfore for him muſt anſwer.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: By your favour, no more friend of mine, then you found him, to claime Kinred: my acquaintance with him, yet is ſcarce a full houre.

sp.speaker: Mer. man.
sp.p:
You are Confederates, and ſo I feare that I ſhall finde you: You know my errand, & promiſt mee diſpatch:
Why am I not diſpatched then?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: My meaning was to give you a Sering, or an inciſion Knife, Of which he told me you did ſtand in need: Indeed I deal in ſuch cōmodities, And am acquainted what ſuch parcels mean: For other wares or mony due for them, I know not what belongs to't.

sp.speaker: Mer. man.
sp.l: Satisfie my Maſter ſo, quit me, and cleer thy ſelf; or 'twill fall foule upon thee.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Willingly: my cloak boy, Ile along, yet am affraid That hee who had profeſt himſelfe thy Kinſman, and my deare friend, will prove thy Maſters Coſin.

div.stage: Enter Lodwick, Tomaſo, Stulitſſimo, Monky, Puſs, &c.

sp.speaker: Puſs.
sp.l: Give you joy Maſter Stultiſſimo; give you joy.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: You talk like Gentlemen, and I like your talk the better, becauſe you talke to a Gentlemen; you call mee Stultiſſimo, and I ſay, Stultorum plena ſunt omnia: and now I talk to you like a Gentleman and a Scholer.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: All health and joy betyde you.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Gramercy Gentlemen, I am not now the man, I was in the morning; I did riſe ſingle, I return double: in the Meridian but Worſhipfull, in the afternoon Honorable before Sun-ſet, and who knows but Majeſticall before mid-night: nay I perſwade my ſelf I am ſo: am I not ſweet Monkie?

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: Thou art my deare Baboon.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Very pretty names in faith: I prethee let's enterchange them ſtill betwixt us: or Marmoſet, or Apes face.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: Yes, yes, by any means.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: All thy goods and chattels, thy moveables, and the ſtuff that belongs thereto, thy utenſils and implements; now are all mine.

sp.speaker: Monk.
sp.l: They are, to have and to hold.

sp.speaker: Puſs.
sp.l: Yes, as long as yee can keep them.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: I have purchaſed thee in thy proper perſon by my word, but all thy other omnium gathrum, beforenamed, by my deeds, I think thou haſt them to ſhew.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: The minde gives ſometimes words unto the tongue, and makes it ſpeak perforce, beare with him Lodwick.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Let the Doctors wife beare with him, for mine own part,
without he renounce this mood, and become ſociable, as hee had wont, I defie his fellowſhip.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Will you dine with me Vallentius?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes, ſhall we be merry?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: O is the tide turn'd, is the winde come about, by this good day, and I were not curſing my ſelfe, for being acceſſary to this melancholy, I have no faith in me; if women can tranſmute men thus ſuddenly, hang me, if I keep not out of their clutches.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Gallants, ſhall wee walk? I have a ſtory for ye: prethee Lodwick frown not, be a friend indeed, and ſee not my defects, I have a tale ſhall make you laugh anon, and will excuſe my blame; prethe be thy ſelfe, be jocund man.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay, I am ſoon perſwaded.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Where ſhall we be?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: At the old houſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come then, I'le make you laugh I ſweare.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Thus by degrees, with hazard of my life, have I attain'd unto my wiſhes reſt; and boldly gaze thee Venice in the face: the time has beene, Oh, but that time is paſt, when I was more familiar with thy pompe, but all that bliſſe is gone: And murther now, has with a crimſon ſtain ſeal'd mee accurſt, and like a condemn'd guilty Fugitive; I wander in deſpaire; fearing the ru •• le of the harmleſſe bird, and the flies clamor, the Ant, the Waſpe, and every leſſer thing, Dreadleſſe of danger, ſtrayes abroad for food; Not caring who behold them, But I, alas, of all; am moſt unhappy: Would I were dead, and paſt the feare of that, Makes mee thus Cowiſh. Who art thou comm'ſt here, more needy then my ſelf?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Where might I run to meet deſtruction, And ſet a period on my wretchedneſſe? Stern miſery I know, and feele thee now: Yet is the earth content to beare my weight, And ſuffer what proud man diſdains to know, Unleſſe to ſpit upon, or add to that, Which wanteth no extream.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I cannot hold: his voice, his humour, I dare ſweare as much, 'tis he; 'Tis he by heaven, my Iulio.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Franciſcus, preſerver of my life; O let mee kiſſe the ground whereon thou treadeſt, then riſe to thank thee.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
That I could ſpend my ſelf to teares for joy, beare witneſſe you that know it: Iulio, for ever dwell within theſe arms
of mine, thou trueſt among men, I have not power to queſtion thee, my danger, my joy is ſo exceſſive; runne all to ſpoyle, & terrour meet with terrour; I feare none my Julio.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Strike when thou wilt proud death, I dare thee now; For having what I wiſht, I wiſh no more, nor would entreate time to deferre a minuite to have him reſt an age, ſince all things muſt have end, end it at once, my prayer is confirm'd, I have ſeene you e're I die.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And if you love me wiſh me not that wrong by praying for your end: doe not quite undoe me, if you but knew my heart, my Julio, you would not crav't againe: I could have comfort now, and cleane forget the dangers I have paſt, and thoſe purſue me ſtill: nothing to come can halfe ſo much diſmay, as thou doſt comfort; be it ſuddaine death or torture worſe than it: but for your ſake, would in my wombe I had bin ſtrangled, and never drawne this aire.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Where art thou Conſcience? whither haſt thou tooke Since thou didſt leave mans breaſt? that wee ſhould all have mothers; VViſedome all, yet all contemne her precepts: when you firſt fled, and by command'ment from the Senate houſe, your ſhips and lands were ſiez'd on for the State, thoſe that which ſtaid them did appeare ſo neare, as if their blood had ty'd them to your ſervice, grew ſo forgetfull in a moments ſpace, that neither argument, nor extreame ſignes could winne them to beliefe there had beene ſuch, as what you were to them: I (as no leſſe I could) bound to't by duty, ſpoke your merits ſtill, and did maintaine your right, on the Allyes of your inconſtant wife: but I am poore for't, truth was ſtill deſpis'd, and leſſe I could not be.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Take all I have▪ had I my former wealth,
My bounty could not recompence thy worth,
And powre it all before thee (my deare Iulio:)
Be not impatient with thy ſufferance, he's above wil pay thee all
My debts, though I ſhould periſh now.
Contemn'd for me? alack, alack, if there be ſuch
A thing in Charity, be charitable: doe not curſe the cauſe
Of this thy preſent want, I doe beſeech thee doe not thou Iulio?
I prethee anſwer me, and either doe what I have wiſht,
Or cure the wound thou haſt made.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Good ſir no more: doe not call all the teares out of mine eyes; think who I am: would you did but know.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I will not urge thee further:
Shall we here combine, and ſhape our courſe alike,
And never, never part; yet pardon me,
I will not wiſh thee ſo much injury
To be unknowne of woman.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: You wiſh me not ſo well, how e're you wiſh, if you wiſh otherwiſe: your miſery be mine, and my enduring yours; one grave receive our bones; and hee that ſayes this Sepulcher is mine, call it Franciſco's Tombe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I have a habite for thee yet unknowne, or worne,
But by my ſelfe: 'tis not a Furlong from the Antique Beech,
Whoſe hollow ſides conceales it: bide but here,
Till I can reach it from the hidden place,
And take it for thine owne: though homely,
Yet the courſeneſſe will keep warme,
And ward the ſharpeſt blaſt.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: You binde me to my prayers.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ile be with thee ſtraight.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Ignorant honeſty, ſhallow Italian, yes, live a wretch: Canſt thou be ſo fond to thinke me of that mettle? haſt thou eyes, and mayſt, yet will not ſee how thou art o're-recht: yes, doe continue innocent, doe, and die a foole, my friend, my friend, my very loyall friend, all friendſhip I forſweare, ſave outward ſignes, which with my garment J caſt nightly off. The father of the ſlaine Antonio promiſes liberally by Proclamation to any that can bring Franciſco forth. I will betray him, I will be the man ſhall purchaſe the reward: What way I curſes, or care for the report the multitude ſhall clamour therein. Ile imitate the Lawyer, making bad words my gaine. Franciſcus thou waſt born for my advancement: he's ſunke himſelfe, and fruitleſſe is the hope depends on that which was, and not which is; give me the preſent, not precedent man. Let me not hanker for emergency, but take the inſtant ſway, the publiſh't recompence is mine, 'tis ſayd, 'tis mine.

div.stage: Franciſcus puts a coat upon him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That any ſhould be falſe—But were there no droſſe, gold could not be eſteem'd, nor nothing precious rare. Cornelia let me forget that name and nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: It is a month and more ſince ſhe left Venice.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Would I had left the world when I firſt ſaw her.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: And the ſame minuite did Phemone forſake her friends and kindred: but where or whither they have betook themſelves the moſt knowing but conjecture.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How eaſie could wee make our miſeries, if wee might live and dye when't pleas'd our ſelves?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Theſe ſtrange additions to my newes I add, Antonio's Carkaſſe never could be found ſince yours and his contention.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I left him dead: thou art ſtill juſt; ſome beaſt has made that fouler beaſt his prey, and made up my revenge: but come with me, let us withdraw unto you thicket by, and ſpeake at large that woefull hiſtory commixt of my proceedings, and purſuith; wilſt time's our owne.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: I would provide me of ſome neceſſaries, ſmall in expence, which make a mighty miſſe, and health cryes out to have: ſo if you pleaſe but let me fit my preſent want, at my returne enjoyne me to your will, though it continue to the lateſt date, and I am ſerviceable.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Speake no more ſuch words, but make your owne content: yet good Iulio be not abſent long, make me not long to ſee thee.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Such ſhall be my ſpeed, you will not wiſh me ſooner to returne.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Not wiſh thee? yes, though thou ſhouldſt make return e're thou depart.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Marke the end.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Be briefe, and goodneſſe take with thee. This Iulio, if deſert might purchaſe Fame, deſerves ſufficient: but thou art partiall Fortune in cramming Buzzards, whilſt the Eagle ſterves: How many in this fertile Italy, whom Nature moulded when ſhe loath'd her taske, and blew her ſeed among the ignorant, haſt thou adorn'd with plenty? whilſt ſeemely vertue, wrackt with poverty, jets under baſe controule: There's no felicity, nor true content here upon earth: The Spider builds his Webbe in Barnes and Palaces: and the Prince himſelfe taſtes gall as hony: Happineſſe there's none, for leaſt or greateſt: Here my griefe ſo parches me, that it does paine me to relate my woes, and make my feelings knowne. Beneath this Hill a cleare and pleaſant
fountaine curles along, whoſe ſhallowneſſe makes the ſmall pibbles 'peare above like Rocks, and murmure as ſhee runnes downe to the ſilver Current, thither will I high, and borrow ſo much of her watry ſtore, as will aſſwage my thirſt:
sp.l: All things are kinde,
And feed our wants when they themſelves are pin'd.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Now my Catter-whauling Puſſe, how didſt thou like my laſt Cheat? did I not foole them finely?

sp.speaker: Puſſe.
sp.l: Thou art the very meere Mephostophelus, and I perſwade my ſelfe thou haſt new vampt thy wits.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Tuſh theſe are nothing: I have cheated one of the braveſt Stats-men of the world; the very quinteſſence of Spaine: Nay, I have fool'd him who boaſted in his Country, he had guld all our Nation A Guelding is not rid in the horſe-faire, but hee is mine to ride, maugre his Maſters teeth. I have out-fac'd a fellow of his horſe in the open Market, ſold him before his face; & but making a queſtion whether he trots or ambles, ride away both with the horſe and mony, my Puſſe. Sweet Munkey looke to the houſe at home, I muſt abroad againe, to fetch in a new purchaſe.

sp.speaker: Puſſe.
sp.l: Maiſt thou thrive according to thy will, and to my wiſhes.

div.stage: Enter Stultiſſimo, Lodwicke, Tomaſo, and two Sorieants.

sp.speaker: 1. Serg.
sp.l: And what's your Action?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Three hundred pound: bee you ready to ſnappe him, and not to eſcape you without good baile: he's as ſlippery as an Eele.

sp.speaker: 2 Serg.
sp.p: Therefore we'le take him by the ſhoulder, and not by the taile; and ſo we ſhall be ſure to hold him. But can you ſhew us the man?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: This is his walk, and without waiting long you may ſpye him.

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.l: Say but that's he, and 'tis enough.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Stand as cloſe as you can: If he have but the leaſt ſuſpition of an arreſt, he's gone in a twinkling.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: But will not you ſtay and aſſiſt us?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p:
By no meunes; Ile but ſee him in huckſters handling, and be gone. Are you not paid your Fees afore-hand, and—
That's he now: Now let him ſcape upon your owne perrill. Farewell.

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.l: If he doe, ſay no more: Yeo man ſtand to me.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Now let me ſee: whom ſhall I next encounter?

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.l: Marry the Counter ſir: for we arreſt you.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Ha, Counterfeits ſo nigh?

sp.speaker: 2 Serg.
sp.l: Yet currant enough to carry you to priſon.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: And yet your Counter-tenour ſounds but like ſcurvy Muſicke: am I catcht then? I pray you at whoſe fuite?

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.l: At three mens ſuite.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Then three merry men, and three merry men be we, are we not honeſt Serjeants? well, there's a peece to begin withall: lets talke further of the buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.p: You ſpeake well ſir, if you hold on as you beginne: and if you can finde good baile, tenne to one but we ſhall prove as you late cald us (Honeſt Serjeants.)

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Me thinks you doe not ſpeak like Varlets:

div.stage: Enter a grave Doctor in ſerious diſcourſe with a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: May it pleaſe you, ſir, to imploy mine induſtry For any further ſervice?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Something more,
Which in my former Letter I forgot,
I would entreat you beare in memory:
And that's but this—

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: And in good time: Know you that reverend man?

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.l: Know him ſir, yes, for a worthy Doctor.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: He's mine owne Vncle: will you take his word.
And make it to me as a free diſcharge?
If he but ſay (nay there's another peece)
Ile ſee you ſatisfied?

sp.speaker: 2 Serg.
sp.l: Yes could we heare him ſay ſo: for hee's one whoſe word will not be queſtioned.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: 'Tis enough:
Give me but ſo much leaue as ſpeake unto him,
All Ile keep in faire diſtance: on my life,
If he • ay not Ile ſee you ſatisfied,
I will returne your priſoner.

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.l:
'Tis enough: for ſo farre we dare truſt you: you have
paid for't well: but we will watch him at an inch.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: I know he will not ſuffer mee to lye
For ſuch a petty ſumme: Now braine or never.
Excuſe my boldneſſe Sir: though it be ſcarce manners,
To interrupt your ſerious conference.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: With me ſir is your buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Such a buſineſſe,
Which as it toucheth me in Charity,
So ſhould it you in Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Speake it pray.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Look well on theſe two men.

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.l: He poynts at us.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: The one is an arch Browniſt, and the other
Cannot endure to ſee a Surpleſſe worne:
Subject indeed to no conformity;
Yet both ſo well perſwaded of your learning,
And ſpotleſſe life, that what you ſhall propoſe
Th'are willing to ſubſcribe too.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I am as ready to give them my inſtructions.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: And pleaſe you ſay ſo, that they may heare you ſir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Well I will:
My honeſt friends, and pleaſe you to have the patience
Till I have ended with this gentleman,
And inſtantly Ile ſee you ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.l: It is enough grave ſir.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Now honeſt Serjeants: what deſire you more?

sp.speaker: 2 Serg.
sp.l: Nothing from you ſir.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: I hope ſo honeſt Serjeant: you ſee I deale fairely.
Farewell my honeſt Serjeants.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I have told you all: only remember me to theſe my noble friends.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: With all the art
My weake tongue can deliver.

sp.speaker: 1 Sergeant.
sp.l: So, he is now at leiſure.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: And now I come to you.

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.l: Moſt welcome, ſir, we ſtay for the ſame purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Now, tell me briefly, which of you is the Browniſt?
which the other, cannot indure a Surplice?

sp.speaker: 2 Serg.
sp.l: You are pleaſant, ſir,
We waite here, hoping to be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: And to that end I ſtay, for theſe opinions
So erroneons and ſo groſſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.l: Sir, all the opinion that we hold is that you will pay us the mony.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Still obſtinate in errour; 'tis this mony,
And worldly care on which ſo much you doate:
Breeds in you theſe diſtractions.

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.l: Pleaſe you to pay the mony, you ſhall finde us conformable in all things.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Mony my friends, are not you Sectaries?

sp.speaker: 2 Serg.
sp.l: Sectaries; no, ſir, we are Sergeants.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Sergeants; and waite for me? I owe you mony?

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.l: Yes, ſir, for your Nephew that was with you but now, and told you of it; & we heard you ſay, you would ſee us ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: The man's to me a ſtranger I proteſt,
And his requeſt was I ſhould ſatisfie you
In ſome points of Religion.

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.l: Religion, ſir, 'tis a theam we ſeldome think of,
But three hundred pound is mony.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: But I tell you,
I paſt my word for counſell not for coine,
And this is all that you from me can have:
Endure a Surplice, and beware a Knave.

sp.speaker: 2 Serg.
sp.l: Had we not warning ſufficient of this before?

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.l: Well, howſoever, we have had good counſell,
If we had the grace to follow it.

div.head: Actus quintus. Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter Arbaces, and Julio in good apparell, with three or foure with weapons.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: ASſure me of the promiſt recompence, I'le bring you to his preſence.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Heare me a word.

div.stage: Enter Vallentius, Lod wick, Tomaſo, Stultiſſimo and Fub.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now Signior, how do you feele you ſelfe? How like you marriage?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Faith it's a pretty quaint thing, and there's much good ſport belongs to't, would I were unmarried again?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why? are you weary of Clariflora already?

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Weary no, but I would have ſtore.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.p: Harke you, ſir, take my counſell; though ſtore be no ſore, meddle with no more of them, leſt you make me a Prophet, and get many a ſore head by the match: have you not heard the ancient ſaying, No man can ſerve two maſters?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: That's true, but any man may ſerve two Miſtreſſes.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: And ſerve their turns well.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay, i'le leave that to the performer.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Hark you Maſter Lodwick, you or any man may thinke he does well, and yet come ſhort.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Briefly, directly, and learnedly ſpoken, ſweet Fub.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: I ſpeak by proof.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Go to, your are a Knave Fub.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: Hold your peace, there's more in the company.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well ſaid, yfaith, thank him Lodwick.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: It's not worth it, though I ſhould ſay as much by you.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: This fellow flows with wit.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.p: Gallants, when were you at Court? I have been deſired thether fortie times, my wife (I thinke) has a hundred friends there: beſides Cooks and Pantlers, that ſhe has had many a good thing of, and they have ſworn to bid me welcome for her ſake.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You may ſee what comes by marriage?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: If we might ſee all that comes by marriage, there would be old butting abroad?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Here's the ſumme, perform thy word, and claime it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good morrow, good Arbaces.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Make me not known to theſe?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Vallentius.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Hee?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Are you not mad, I heard no leſſe of late.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Report's a calumnious quean, and will abuſe vertue it ſelf you ſee, both what he is, and what he was?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: I am not ſorrie, that I am deceiv'd: heare you not of Franciſcus.

div.stage: Exit Arbaces with Julio, and the Watch.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Upon my credit nothing.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Faire be your companie, come Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What's he that throws his Cloake about his noſe?
Is it not Iulio?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: By all exterior ſeeming?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My life 'tis he?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What ſhould this mean?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I was asking that.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Mark't you Arbaces: he hath ſome drift in hand.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Did you not note his followers?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes, and the Arms they carried.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Shall we trace them, firs? and leave our wonder: I dare gage my life, the knowledge will deſerve the induſtry?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: You ſpeake my words.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Hee named Franciſcus.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes, and queſtion'd me.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Withall, obſerv'd you but his ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come, wee will purſue him.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: La, la, la, la: nay, I pray take me with you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: If not for company, for mirth's ſake, take heed before there.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: In mightie men how great appears the vertue nere ſo ſmall; how ſmall the vice, though mighty Philoſophie, they rules bridles my cogitations, and prolongs, what manhood would diſdain, the time to come appales my courage and ſtrikes inſtant feares through every nerve and artery: might wee like beaſts end when wee die, and never make account in no other place then heer: what heart ſo baſe would feare the threatning Law? Flatter the Judge to ſave him: I would not ſure: but there is bliſſe and torment much to come, wee cannot thinke on't yet the Reſurrection aws me, I am much diſtempered, and want of companie, begets in me millions of terrours: Iulio tarries long, my Oriſons ſecure him, could the teares waſh the bloud but of my hands, my minde were ſomething free.

div.stage: Enter Julio mufled, Arbaces and a Guard.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: This is the place, and there Franciſcus walks.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: That's he: apprehend him, i'le not be ſeen in't.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Your office, ſir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What are theſe for men.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Lay hands upon him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What mean you friends?

sp.speaker: Conſtable.
sp.l: This we mean to attach you, as a murderer.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Arbaces, I am betray'd.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.p: Look to the homicide, ſuch mercie as a Tiger yields his prey, when he's pincht for want of what's his booty, expect from me thou murtherer.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: None I have deſerv'd, or am about to crave, I know the worſt, my life thou canſt but have, 'Tis thine; I make a tender of it ere the ſentence come, & give thy labour eaſe, alas, poor Iulio: thou wilt unfriended, run thy future race without ſocietie, I pitty thee my friend more then my ſelfe, danger to me is ſuch, I do expect and dread not. Fare thee well, my breach of promiſe, is not with my will, but meerly on conſtraint.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Lead him hence.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Here they are.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Who have we here bound to the good behaviour? Franciſcus!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: My deare friend.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: My brother.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Officers, why doe you linger thus, away with him?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: How fare you, ſir?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Sicke, ſicke to death Vallentius: ſhall wee hence?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I now behold my feare, when I did heare Arbaces ſpeak of him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Something of badneſſe ſhoot me inſtantly, but hee does pierce me through.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Good Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Has he recided here ſince he firſt fled?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I thought him now in Millain, where hee did trafficke much.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I wonder how he came to be diſcovered?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Beſhrew my bloud, I pitty his eſtate.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Will you accord with mee, ſhew that reſpect you once did tender him, and withall willingnes ſtrive to invent a means may do him eaſe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What, my ſword, my word, or wealth can doe is his, command it for him?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let us petition to his rough adverſary, and like true Suppliants in our own behalfs, draw mercy from Arbaces.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: About it then, and our intentions thrive. Manet Julio.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: The gold is mine, his certain bondage does aſſure mee it, why ſhould I be an Aſſe, and nicely ſtand on that no Tradeſman does: no thrifty one, what conſcience, any thing but ſuch a word: our wiſe divines that preach an't, know it not, nor make good uſe of that, or ought they ſay, but of good mony: this I daily ſee, and ſometime make my daily meditation, all's Ceremonie compos'd for purpoſe:
sp.l: But be it what it will, this is my grace,
If not for one, I'me for the othe place.

div.stage: Enter the Duke of Venice, two Senators, Criſſipus, Arbaces, Vallentius, Tomaſo, Lodwick, Clarke, and others.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Bring the offender forth.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Have mercie, good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Believe't thou mayſt ſooner move a rock, which neither bluſtring winde, nor boiſterous Sea could ſhake or ſwallow, then beget remorſe or ſmalleſt favour in ſo foule a caſe: I were unjuſt, and much unmeet to be the man I am, ſhould wee ſhew mercie where the crime deſerves, beyond the laws extent. He that ſhall pardon murder, take't from me, is acceſſary to the guilty deed, and ſtands in ſelf predicament: Heaven defend we ſhould be ſuch, were he my Nephew, nay, my firſt-borne ſonne, or one more neere: let me not be bleſt in my proceedings, if our Authoritie ſhould blinde his ſinne, or alter juſtice courſe, ſet him forth: what favour equitie can yield be his, no more expect Criſippus.

sp.speaker: Pri. Sen.
sp.l: Read the indictment.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Save that pains, guilty, nor do repent, that in my wrath I did, whereof I ſtand convict.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Art thou not ſorrie for thy hainous crime?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No mighty ſir, but rather joy the more, in that it breviats my paſſage here, which I would willingly leave.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Impudent homicide: juſtice good my Lord, with that ſeveritie which they deſerve, which wilfully commit—

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Ariſe, thou needſt not kneele, nor beg for juſtice, be aſſured Arbaces: ſuch his deſervings, ſuch his puniſhment, and cruell
as the cauſe, thou moſt bruitiſh man, nay, beaſt or ſomething worſe: hadſt thou no humanitie, no ſparke of reaſon then, nor ſence, to thinke thy treſpaſſe foule and ugly? do'ſt not repent thy tyranny in death, though not the deed it ſelf: fie on thee monſter, haſt thou a foule and dreadſt not her perdition: what heathen ſavage, nay, what ruder thing, having the life thou ſoughtſt, would have enacted ſuch a deed of ruth, as thou, thou worſt of creatures, on the image and liveleſſe carcaſſe of thy loving friend.

sp.speaker: Pri. Sen.
sp.l: 'Twas moſt uncivill, moſt unchriſtianly.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.l: An act, a Tigre would not have perform'd, on one that had ſlain his brood.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Heare me good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: My poore Antonio.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That I did take his life, I have confeſt, what further accuſations laid on mee, is meerly malice, and proceed from ſome, could wiſh my torment worſe.

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Out on thee butcher: give me leave my Lord.

sp.speaker: Clark.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Canſt thou deny thy wrathfull crueltie, impetuous tyranny, and fell revenge upon his bleeding trunk?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Unleſſe I ſhould belie my ſelfe, and ſpeake like a vaine boaſter, more then what I did, I muſt ſay this is falſe, and hee's from truth, as farre as I am from hope of life, begot this ſlander.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Produce your proofe Arbaces, ſtrike bluſhes through the cheeks of this falſe man, and let him ſee his ſhame.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What Devill ſhould be rais'd from the loweſt hell, to juſtifie this wrong?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: This is ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I never thought Franciſcus one ſo foule, as I behold him now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not thought, I durſt have ſworn him of a purer mettle▪ and better temper farre.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Proſperitie to the Venetian State.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Iulio: he's not his proof I hope.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is this the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: This is he my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Make room, give way there.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How comes this about?

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.p: The fact's confeſt, my Lord, what need we further wade into the Law, or heap on troubles which we may eſchew, upon ſo plain a caſe? the crime is Murder, Murder is confeſt, then as you finde the guilt, proceed to judgement, and make no further queſtion.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We ſhall be ſuddain.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My ſentence, good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Speake, ſir, can you report any thing more touching this buſineſſe then what already is delivered here in the open Court.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: No more or leſſe, then what his owne tongue uttered, can I or have to ſay.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: We were once friends: once had I ſuch opinion of his vertues, my life and eſtimation were both his, hee might command them, much it were to ſpeake of all that paſt between us: thus in ſhort, I would ſome other were compell'd to this, which you have tied me too, my neereſt friend alive.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Arbaces: was this the man gave you firſt notice where this Murderer kept?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: The ſame my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Did he betray me? can this be.

sp.speaker: 2 Sen.
sp.l: Forward.

sp.speaker: 1 Sen.
sp.l: Speake.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Muſt we be enforc'd, what ſhould I ſpeak, hee flue him, ript his bowels, mangled him, and in his wrath, as man will any thing: tumbled his reeking quarters downe a Vault moſt ſteep and lothſome: what of this, hee might deſerve much worſe auſteritie, yet this was bad enough?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Arba.
sp.l: Juſtice, gracious Prince, juſtice, juſtice, ſir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is this truth?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Let me be depos'd—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The moſt erronious, execrable part that ever was perform'd.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Were hee my father, ſhould forget himſelfe, and match this outrage, mercy quite forſake me if I would ſue his pardon.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: It was ruthleſſe, fell, and bloudie.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Look not up for ſhame, thou haſt no intereſt there.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I have done wrong, mightie, mightie wrong.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Canſt thou behold it now?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Pardon me father, pardon good Arbaces: that villaine, that foule villaine.

div.stage: Enter Antonio, Cornelia, Phemone, and Shepheard.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.l: 'Twas time to come.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Shew mercie, mercie, Duke.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Pittie our complaints, have ſome compaſſion.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What are theſe that make this earneſt deprecation, with ſuch a heartie zeale; are they well known to this aſſembly?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Cornelia, ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Faire Phemone.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: When will theſe humid fountains be dried up, and yield no more warme drops?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: My ſweet Franciſcus.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Some good or bad thing fell mee ſuddenly, let mee behold no more.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is that his wife?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She was my Lord, while ſome hard fate diſ-joyn'd their mutuall league, and burſt the holy concord.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Wilt thou pardon me and live a happie one, when I am dead, and lapt in this cold earth.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Franciſcus I was ever true to you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I ſee it, and believe: that villaine, oh, that villaine!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Harken thy ſentence.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Heare mee my good Lord, little I have to ſay, yet to much grief tend my few words, this traitor, nay, 'tis title all too good for one ſo hainous foule, that he is perjur'd, by the death I owe his lateſt words do witneſſe what hee is more, and worſe: with pardon Lords, I ſhall delate at large, that all hereafter may example take, and ſhun a villaines ſnare; I tooke him up, when like an Adder in the froſty dew, the cold had ſtarved him: that I had ſet my foot upon his head, when to my boſome I did take the Serpent, not cheriſht, comforted long had he been, but hee both bit and ſtung mee: fooliſh man I was to be ſo fond, not many months, nor happy days I had with this moſt trueſt, moſt immaculate piece, but that perfidious Caitiffe, that blacke fiend by ſtrange ſuggeſtions, and invented projects, draws mee into a confirm'd jealouſie, that ſhe had ſtained her honour, falſly playd
with young Antonio.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: O forgive me heaven, what is this?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I from my wrong conceiv'd, leaſt could I not, Drew him apart into a ſilent Grove, Having before vow'd ſolemnly revenge, Where I made ſome repetition of my griefe: he ſtill (I ſee him) innnocent gentleman, taking my words For ſuch as Lovers uſe, when they are wanton, Smiles me in the face, and would not thing 'twas anger.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tis truth he ſpeakes.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: This inkindled me, and as Boare,
When he does chaw his foame, predicts ſome miſchiefe,
So my bended front fore-told his ruine,
Forth I drew my ſword, and ſheathed it
Within his breaſt, what elſe is added,
He's a Jew averres, and falſer than a whore.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: See, ſee the Ages wickedneſſe: can it be poſſible?
sp.p: O miſerable time, when men make no more reckoning of their ſoules! Fye, fye, Franciſco, thinke upon your end, and whither you muſt goe. Moſt reverend Fathers, obſerve you this his contumacy: I ſhall I feare be forc'd to ſpeak what in my heart till now I cheſted, and rib'd in, becauſe mine oath, 'twas not my wil hath heare conſtrained me to expoſe his blame, my ſoule had vowed to hide; Note into malice how he throwes himſelfe, and would ſtaine my reputation with a calumnious lye.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Art thou a man, or ſomething elſe; oh foole, foole.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is this poſſible?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Give eare unto thy ſentece.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I muſt, in—

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Did not I ſay he's mad, ſtarke raving mad, away with him. The man's alive that's dead.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes, they ſupt together: I love this fellow.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Your Grace ſhall doe well to puniſh this ſaucy groom.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are a moſt pernicious damn'd villaine, and your ſoule knowes it.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Come, ſir, depart, & rave not, or I ſhall ſee you whipt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Good Father pardon; pardon mighty Duke, pardon Antonio, cauſe of this diſquiet. Lod. Antonio?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: By this light he ſupt with him indeed.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is not ſo, this cannot be.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Is there no mountaine nigh to fall on me, no roten houſe?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I know not whether I may call thee ſonne, or reſt in doubt for ever.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am Antonio, and I was your ſon, when I left Venice laſt.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Is no man here amaz'd but onely I?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: My deare Phemone!

sp.speaker: Phem.
sp.l: Were you the Shepheard?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You ſee chaſte Cornelia.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Was ever man ſo bleſt?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, come Franciſco, I muſt have your hand: I can as well forgive, as I can love; and nothing more than both: good Criſſippus, my old friend.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You have bin a ſtranger Signior; but I'me glad 'tis thus.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Whither away: ſtay him officers; wee have not done with you.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Wither ſhall I runne to hide my ſelfe?
What Climate, or what Region? Pardon greateſt Prince.
Pardon grave Fathers.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Againſt that prayer kneele I:
No pardon Prince, as thou doſt hope for bliſſe.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Grant him a halter; nothing elſe good Duke.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Give him his liberty: Art thou ſo impudent to pleade for mercy, and beg of me, having committed ſuch a capitall treſpaſſe here in my view?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Though what I ſpeake, with ſome additions, I have done and more, and he more falſe has plaid, than I have ſaid, blot his offences: be propitious Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Though the greateſt ſufferance fell on my part, I here acquit him, and beſeech for mercy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yet be compendious, and poſſeſſe this preſence, what cauſe thou hadſt that tempted thee ſo badly to ſeek my ruine.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: The Devill and his Angels.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O fie Ioretzo.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How Ioretzo? not the ſonne of that pernitious traytor, had plotted with Lamunes for ſummes of gold to burn our City?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: He's dead, and ſuffered for the ſame offence.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l:
When brought the toad forth other than himſelfe, unleſſe
'twere ſomething worſe?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Forget his Fathers faults: be pittifull.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: He that prayes next in his behalfe, by heaven friends not himſelf, and is mine enemy: We have too long ſuffered ſuch Weeds as theſe to flouriſh in our ſoyle: No more the boſome of this earth of ours, ſhall (like a mother) lend her fruitleſſe encreaſe, to cheriſh thoſe would bane her: The ſword of juſtice cut the juſtice off that keeps it ſheath'd to ſuch: His deeds were ſhamefull, his rewards be ſo, and quittance his deſert: S • are on his brow in letters cappitall, the name of knave, that all behold may reade him what he is, and hate him in the ſight: His next doome is this; after three daies we charge thee on thy life, never ſet foote more in thy Native Climate.
sp.l: So, beare him to his torture, ſpeech is vaine:
For what is ſaid there's nothing can reſtraine.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Moſt worthy Prince.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Ile be honeſter while I live for this trick.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Can you forgive mine injury, Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: As freely as I hope to be forgiven; and crave no more amends, but onely this you'le call me brother, and make Phemone mine.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I need not make what's made, take and enjoy her that hath vow'd to be none but yours.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Thy hand Arbaces, our quarrell's or'e, we'le no fighting.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Fight, yes: I hope we ſhall find ſomething elſe to doe.

sp.speaker: Criſ.
sp.l: Daughter I have done thee wrong too; but Ile ſeeke forgiveneſſe when we have more leaſure.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: This day breeds wonders: by what accident ſcapt you of your wounds?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Here ſtands the meanes, whom I muſt ever tender with reſpect, as with my full proceedings you ſhall heare, when none can interrupt.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Franciſco, henceforth know your vertuous wife, & prize her as a jewell: I have heard the world ſpeake well of her, and thoſe unmatch'd wiſh they may have your fortunes. Lodwicke where's the dumbe ſhew you promis'd me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Even ready my Lord; but may be cald a motion: for puppits wil ſpeak but ſuch corrupt language, you'le never underſtand without an interpreter, or a ſhort plot; which I have drawn
thus—Now the motion followes.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: What not divulge: yes, yes, I will divulge.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: The jealous Doctor: I have him.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Doe me right, ſweet Duke, doe me right.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: What art?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: A foole, a phyſitian, a maintainer of whoredome, with a poxe to me.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Then Medice cura teipſum; more knave than foole, the plot's falſe drawne elſe: away with em.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Come ſir, depart.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Purge mee Duke, purge me, or let my wife take out my corrupted braines, and rince them in a Cucking-ſtoole: I come Skimmington, I come.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Vallentius you muſt take ſome order for the Doctors cure: he befriended you in as great a courteſie.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: Trot on afore: is the Corne-cutter come yet?

sp.speaker: Fub.
sp.l: The Horne-cutter is come, ſir.

sp.speaker: Stult.
sp.l: On, on to the Leaguer then: I am aſhamed to ſhow my head amongſt Animalls: on to the Leaguer.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This is a Monſter of your making, Lodwicke, buy him a Cap-caſe to hide up his hornes in, for ſhame o'th' world.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Come we are both—

div.stage: A great Hubub and noiſe, a ringing of baſons, a great many Boyes before, and Julio drawne in a Cart.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.l: He comes, he comes.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.l: Where doth he come? hee is rather drawne hither like a Bare to a ſtake.

sp.speaker: 3 Boy.
sp.l: What in a Coach?

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: Nay, rather in an open Charriot: and yet it cannot bee properly called a Chariot, becauſe it runnes but on two Wheeles.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.l: Roome for him there: for I am ſure hee had rather any here had his roome than his company.

sp.speaker: 3 Boy.
sp.l: Silence there; you in the Docket there, let but one ſpeake in the Court at once.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: Noverint univerſi,
It is the Dukes mercy;
And the condition of my Obligation,
To make my recantation,
That I within bound,
Should give reaſons profound,
Why (much againſt my heart)
I thus ride in a Cart.
sp.p: Nay, gentlemen, no egges I beſeech you: for I love them at this time, neither raw, roaſted, nor rotten. For ſhould they hit me on the breaſt, they would goe cleane againſt my ſtomacke.

div.stage: Tomaſo in a corner of the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: You Phaeton.
Is that your Father Phoebus his Chariot, and will he allow you never a Boxe to ſit in?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: No juglers Boxe, Ile aſſure thee friend: for here's neither paſſe, nor repaſſe, I ſtand here you ſee for an example, And could wiſh all theſe good people to follow it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Who's that, Bootes mounted in his Charles waine? doth he cry Pippings, Carrets, or Turneps?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: You are deceived, Signior: rather Bread, and Meate, as Pye-cruſt, bones, and fragments out of the Ludgate mans basket: Nay, hold your hands, I beſeech you Gentlemen, and uſe your tongues and ſpare not.

sp.speaker: Stul.
sp.l: Well, he ſtands heare but for a ſhew, and I am ſure I ſuffered for it really and indeed.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Beare witneſſe my Maſters, that is the maine malefactor indeed, and I ſtand here for a ſhow: Ile goe no further than his owne confeſſion.

sp.speaker: Country fel.
sp.p: They talke of Cheaters, here is a twenty ſhillings peece that I put into my mouth, let any Cheater in Chriſtendome couſen me of this, and carry it away cleanly, and Ile not only forgive him, but hugge him and imbrace him for it, and ſay he is a very Hocus Pocus indeed.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: What ſaid that fellow?

sp.speaker: Puſſe.
sp.l: He ſaith he hath a peece in his mouth, that all Europe ſhall not cheate him of.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: I have markt him, 'tis mine owne: and notwithſtanding all this melancholy we'le ſpend it at night in Wine and Muſicke.

sp.speaker: Count. fel.
sp.p: Hee that can plucke this peece out of my jawes, ſpight of my teeth, and I keepe my mouth faſt ſhut, Ile ſay hee is more than a Cheater, and a Doctor Fauſtus, or Mephoſtophilus at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Puſs.
sp.l: Doſt heare how he brags?

sp.speaker: Jullio.
sp.l: 'Tis mine own I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: 1 Count.
sp.l: But what's become of my horſe?

sp.speaker: 2 Count.
sp.l: And what's become of my load of hay?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: May I eate hay with your horſe, if they were not both done neatly and cleanly. But Gentlemen, and the reſt, you ſee I am at this preſent your pittifull ſpectacle. I lookt once within this twelve month, not to have been mounted in ſuch ſtate: but no man knows what preferment hee is born to. You ſee I have hitherto ſayled through this great ſtorme without ſoyling my Suite, ſpoyling my Ruffe, or ſpattering my Beaver: thanks to theſe kinde ſpectators.

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.l: But Maſter Faſt and Looſe; doe you remember what a ſlippery trick you ſerved Maſter Doctor and us?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: And was it not fairely done Maſter Sergeant, to teach you how to diſgeſt the wearing of a Surplice, before you came to ſtand in a white ſheet.

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.l: Well now you are at your journies end: May it pleaſe you to alight for your eaſe?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Withall my heart: and if either you or any of my accuſers be weary with following me on foot, the Room is now empty, I will give him leave to ride in my place. Hee ſeems to fall into a paſſion. Yet when I doe but think of this diſaſter, it draws teares from mine eyes.
sp.l: He draws his handkerchiefe (as to wipe his eyes) juſt before the Country fellow, and ſcatters ſome ſmall mony.

sp.speaker: Country fellow.
sp.l: Sir, you have (I think) let fall ſome mony.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Thanks honeſt friend.

sp.speaker: Count. fel.
sp.l: What do you look for? I can aſſure you here is all that fell.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l:
Nay, ſure I had more mony? 'tis not in my handkerchief,
nor in my pockets, I have examined them both.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: Why, what do you want ſir?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: A piece, a piece, and had it now, juſt now; ſure whilſt I was ſo high pearcht none could dive ſo low into my pocket, it was ſure as I lighted, and dropt from mee, juſt as I drew my handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Puſs.
sp.l: Some ſuch thing I ſaw fall.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Pray who were they that ſtoopt?

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: I ſaw none ſtoop but this Country fellow.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Then ſir, I muſt demand this piece of you.

sp.speaker: Count. fellow.
sp.l: Of me? I profeſſe I tooke up but two ſhillings and ſix pence, and that I gave into your hand.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: But I profeſſe that one of them was a piece, and never came into my hand, and that I muſt demand of you: ſay did no body ſtoop but hee?

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: None I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Thou art ſtill my honeſt Sergeant.

sp.speaker: Puſs.
sp.l: That fellow hath ſomething in his mouth.

sp.speaker: Count. fel.
sp.l: Yes my tongue and my teeth, and what of all that.

sp.speaker: Puſs.
sp.l: Nay, ſomething elſe ſure, for hee is not troubled with the Mumps, and yet ſee how one ſide of his cheeks bumps out.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: I am afraid, we ſhall finde him a Cheater.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: Sirrah know I am an Officer, I charge you open your mouth, and let us ſee what you have in it, &c.

sp.speaker: Count. fel.
sp.l: Well ſir, I have a twenty ſhillings piece, what then?

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: And this man miſſeth a twenty ſhilling piece out of his pocket.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Plead well Sergeant and thou ſhalt have thy ſee.

sp.speaker: Count. fel.
sp.l: Well, there it is, what can you make of it?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Marry twenty ſhillings good and lawfull currant mony, Puſs, was not this the piece that I put in my pocket this morning?

sp.speaker: Puſs.
sp.l: I know it by that mark.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: And ſhe's witneſſe ſufficient in conſcience.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Doe you ſee Gentlemen. I am here brought to publike penance for a Cheater, and here's a plain fellow that (it ſeems) in his ſimplicity would out-doe me: if I be thus cenſured meerly for ſuſpicion; ſhall hee ſcape free that is taken in the very action?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: No, no, mount him, mount him.

sp.speaker: Count. fel.
sp.p: Nay, by your favour Gentlemen, I have driven a Cart often for my pleaſure, and would bee loth to ride in one now for my puniſhment. It is penance enough for mee to part with my peece, which cannot be more currant of Coine, then his is Arrant for Knavery.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: He's gone, I am ſtill here, now Gentlemen,
If heretofore there hath been any Doll,
Any bold Beachum, and any Cut-purſe Moll.
Any Bawd fat with wealth, or with care meager,
That ſpends her time in Garriſon or Leager,
Grace me ſo farre to ſay, that of a Cheater
Though ſome have been more grave; ſcarce any greater,
But Gentlemen; what need we more repeating?
Knowing, that even in all Trades there is cheating?
Tis common both in buying and in ſelling,
In all Commerce; nay, even in mony telling.
Tis frequent 'twixt the Pander and the Whore,
We our ſelves finde it at the Play-houſe doore.
And though (for an example) here I ſtand,
I am not all the Cheaters in the land.
Some here (no queſtion) know it but I vow,
(They what they pleaſe) I will cheat none of you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We underſtand their humours,
And the cauſe of their diſtempers;
And have too long ſuffered ſuch weeds
As theſe to flouriſh in our ſoyle,
But now no longer ſhall this earth of ours,
Like a • inde Mother lend her fruits increaſe,
To cheriſh thoſe would eclipſe her worth.
But thoſe whoſe aymes and acts are imitable,
Crown with green Garlands, and with Bowls brim'd full.
Muſique proclaime a generall Feſtivall,
A Jubile of joy and mirth to all:
May love and truth, never like comfort miſſe,
Nor Knave in Grain, ſcape a reward like this.
